div.p: A True Widow. A COMEDY, Acted by the DUKE's Servants.
LONDON, Printed for Benjamin Tooke, at the Ship in St. Paul's Church-yard. 1679.

div.head: To Sir Charles Sedley.
div.p: THIS Play, which I here recommend to your Protection, either through the Calamity of the Time, which made People not care for Diversions, or through the Anger of a great many, who thought themselves concerned in the Satyr, or through the want of taste in others, met not with that Success from the generality of the Audience, which I hop'd for, and you thought, and still think, it deserved; and I have the Judgment of Men of the best Sense, besides the best of the Poets, on my side in this Point.

But no Success what-ever, could have made me alter my Opinion of this Comedy, which had the benefit of your Correction and Alteration, and the honour of your Approbation: And I heartily wish, you had given your self the trouble, to have review'd all my Plays, as they came incorrectly and in hast from my hands; 'twould have been more to my advantage, than the assistance of Scipio and Laelius was to Terence; and I should have thought it at least as much to my Honour, since by the effects, I find I cannot but esteem you to be as much above both of them in Wit, as either of them was above you in Place in the State.

I shall not, according to the Custom of Dedications, make a Declamation upon your Wit, the common Theam of all that have any, at least of such as know you, who will acknowledge, they have heard more of it drop carelesly from your Mouth, than they have ever seen from the labouring Pen of any other. And my greatest satisfaction is, that I have the Honour of his Friendship, and my Comedies have had his Approbation, whom I have heard speak more Wit at a Supper, than all my Adversaries, with their Heads joyn'd together, can write in a year. Nor are your Writings unequal to any Man's of this Age, (not to speak of abundance of excellent Copies of Verses) you have in the Mulberry-Garden shown the true Wit, Humour, and Satyr of a Comedy; and in Antony and Cleopatra, the true Spirit of a Tragedy, the only one (except two of Johnson's, and one of Shakespear's) wherein
Romans are made to speak and do like Romans: there are to be found the true Characters of Antony and Cleopatra, as they were; whereas a French Author would have made the Aegyptian and the Roman both become French 〈◊〉 his Pen. And even our English Authors are too much given to make 〈◊〉 History (in their Plays) Romantick and impossible; but in this Play, the Romans are true Romans, and their Style is such: and I dare affirm, that there is not in any Play of this Age so much of the Spirit of the Classick Authors, as in your Antony and Cleopatra. This Opinion I have, unbiass'd by my Friendship, and the Obligations which I owe to you, often declared, and shall always persist in.

After all this, since my Comedies are approved and commended by you, and Men of your sort, the rest of the Audience must forgive me, if I am much more exalted by the praise of such as you, than I can ever be humbled by their censure.

Satyr will be always unpleasant to those that deserve it. It was not my design in this Play to please a Bawd of Quality, a vain Selfish, a sensless, noisie Prig, a methodical Blockhead, having only a form of Wisdom, or a Coxcomb that's run stark mad after Wit, which uses him very unkindly, and will never be won by him; nor did I think to please the Widdows in the Name. The three first of these Characters are wholly new, not so much as touch'd upon before, and the following ones are new in the greatest part. And till I see more variety of new Humour, than I have produced in my Comedies, and more naturally drawn, I shall not despair of bearing up near my Contemporaries of the first rate, who write Comedy, and of always surmounting the little Poetasters of the fourth rate, who condemn me; such as hold, that Wit signifies nothing in a Comedy; but the putting out of Candles, kicking down of Tables, falling over Joynt-stools, impossible accidents, and unnatural mistakes, (which they most absurdly call Plot) are the poor things they rely upon: But'tis the Opinion of the best Poets, that the Story of a Play ought to be carried on, by working up of Scenes naturally: by design, not accidents. I have endeavour'd to do so in this Play, and I doubt not, but the Scene in the second Act, wherein La. Busy would perswade Isabella to be kept, will live, when the Stuff of such Scriblers (more fit for Drolls than Plays) shall be consumed in Grocery-ware, Tobacco, Band-boxes, and Hat-cases, and be rased out of the memory of Men.

I should not say so much in my own behalf, if I had not met with palpable injustice from some, whose design is to set up Quacks, and put down true Professors; nor can I find any Reason, why a Man that is to live by his Wit, should not vindicate that, when 'tis traduced, as well as he, who is to live by his Reputation, may assert his Honesty, when 'tis aspersed especially since neither of 'em are qualities of a Man's own making. But I must ask your pardon,
for troubling you so long with my Resentments, when I should be boasting of the many Favours you have done me, and giving you my thanks for 'em; yet I know you look for no returns where you oblige; however I am too proud of your Kindness to conceal it, and therefore shall take all opportunities I can publickly to declare my self,

closer.signed: Your most obliged humble Servant, Tho. Shadwell.

lg.l: HEav'n save ye Gallants, and this hopeful Age,
Y'are welcome to the downfal of the Stage:
The Fools have labour'd long in their Vocation;
And Vice, (the Manufacture of the Nation)
O're stocks the Town so much, and thrives so well,
That Fopps and Knaves grow Druggs, and will not sell.
In vain our Wares on Theaters are shown,
When each has a Plantation of his own.
His Cruse ne'r fails; for whatsoe're he spends,
There's still God's plenty for himself and friends.
Shou'd Men be rated by Poetick Rules,
Lord what a Poll would there be rais'd from Fools!
Mean time poor Wit prohibited must lye,
At if 'twere made some French Commodity.
Fools you will have, and rais'd at vast expence,
And yet as soon as seen, they give offence.
Time was, when none would cry that Oaf was mee,
But now you strive about your Pedigree:
Bawble and Cap no sooner are thrown down,
But there's a Muss of more than half the Town.
Each one will challenge a Child's part at least,
A sign the Family is well increas'd
Of Forreign Cattle! there's no longer need,
When w'are supply'd so fast with English Breed.
Well! Flourish, Countrymen: drink swear and roar,
Let every free-born Subject keep his Whore;
And wandring in the Wilderness about,
At end of 40 years not wear her out.
But when you see these Pictures▪ let none dare
To own beyond a Limb, or single share:
For where the Punk is common! he's a Sot,
Who needs will Father what the Parish got.

list.label: Bellamour,
list.item: A Gentleman of the Town, who had retired some time into the Countrey.
list.label: Carlos,
list.item: A Gentleman return'd from Travel, with Wit enough left to love his own Countrey.
list.label: Stanmore,
Selfish,
list.item: A Coxcomb conceited of his Beauty, Wit and Breeding, thinking all Women in Love with him, always admiring and talking of himself.
list.label: Old Maggot.
list.item: An old credulous Fellow, a great Enemy to Wit, and a great Lover of Business, for Business-sake.
list.label: Yo. Maggot.
list.item: His Nephew: An Inns of Court-Man, who neglects his Law, and runs mad after Wit, pretending much to Love, and both in spight of Nature, since his Face makes him unfit for one, and his Brains for the other.
list.label: Prig,
list.item: A Coxcomb that never talks or thinks of any thing but Dogs, Horses, Hunting, Hawking, Bowls, Tennis, and Gameing; a Rook, a most noisie Jockey.
list.label: Lump,
list.item: A methodical Blockhead, as regular as a Clock, and goes as true as a Pendulum, one that knows what he shall do every Day of his Life by his Almanack, where he sets down all his Actions before-hand, a mortal Enemy to Wit..
list.label: La. Cheat.
list.item: The true Widdow, that comes to Town, and makes a show of a Fortune, to put off her self, and her two Daughters.
list.label: Isabella,
list.item: Her Eldest, a Woman of Wit and Vertue.
list.label: Gartrude,
list.item: Her Youngest, very foolish and whorish.
list.label: La. Busy,
list.item: A Woman of Intrigue, very busie in Love-Matters of all kinds, too old for Love of her own, always charitably helping forward that of others, very fond of young Women, very wise and discreet, half Bawd, half Match-maker.

div.p: MAny Faults in the Printing have escaped, by reason of my absence, while the third and fourth Acts were in the Press: I shall only give you an account of some notorious Errours; as Page 44. for 5 s. read 50 l. p. 47. for in favour r. infamous. p. 48. instead of 〈◊〉 〈◊〉 r. take me: But the greatest Mistake was, in not printing the Play in the Play in another Character, that that might be known in the Reading, which a great many did not 〈◊〉 in the Acting of it; but take notice, 2 Lovers, Wife and Husband, are all that speak in that. In the Action, many 〈◊〉 which belong'd to the Farce in the Play, and which to the Play it self, by reason of promiscuous speaking; and I found by venturing upon that new Thing, I ran a great Risque: For some, I believe, wish'd all the Play like that part of a Farce in it; others knew not my intention in it, which was to expose the Style and Plot of Farce-Writers, to the utter confusion of damnable Farce, and all its wicked and soolish Adherents. But I had rather suffer, by venturing to bring new things upon the Stage, than go on like a Mill-Horse in the same Round.

div.head: A True Widow.
ACT I.

sp.speaker: Stan.
sp.p: COme Bellamour, what not drest yet? methinks after so long a fast from Wit and fine Women as you have had in the Countrey, you should be sharper set after both, than to fool away a morning thus in your Chamber.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: There is a respect due from a Countrey Gentleman to a new Suit and Peruque, they must not be hastily put on. And the Women of this Town, if you don't take care of your own outside, will never let you be acquainted with their insides.

sp.speaker: Stan.
sp.p: Thou art mistaken, men succeed now according to the Clothes they give, not those they wear.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Amongst your little Whores, Stanmore.

sp.speaker: Stan.
sp.p: And amongst your great Whores too Bellamour. I knew a Gentleman, who was so ugly, a modish Spark would scarce have given him a Livery. yet by a correspondence he kept with a Taylor, and Shoomaker at Paris, and two or three of that sort, got one of the finest Women in England.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: How so?

sp.speaker: Stan.
sp.p: Why she had always the fashion a month before any of the Court-Ladies, never wore any thing made in England, scarce washt there, and had all the affected new Words sent her, before they were in print, which made her pass among Fops for a kind of French Wit..

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: But were not these French Petticoats, though given by one man, taken up by many.

sp.speaker: Stan.
sp.p: 'Faith I think not, she considered her own vanity above any mans address, though one Lord made Coaches at her, another squeezed in his fat sides at her, till he looked like a full sack; a third writ lamentable Sonnets to her; a fourth observed her motions in the Park, which, by the way is the new method of making Love.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: What, do they make Love without speaking to one another?

sp.speaker: Stan.
sp.p: A great many very sine Gentlemen, to look at, better then with it, your side glass let down 〈◊〉, when the party goes by, is very 〈◊〉 if she side glass you again, for that s●…the new word, ply her next day with a billet doux and you have her sure.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: What if we chance to go the same way, or she won't receive my billet doux, as you call it?

sp.speaker: Stan.
sp.p: For the first it must never chance; you must instruct your Coachman, and for the second after such an advance as side-glassing of you▪ if she refuse your Billet she is a Jilt, and you must rail at her in all Companies.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: I am pretty good at railing, but not so good as thou art, Stanmore.

sp.speaker: Stan.
sp.p: I had forgotten half; you must turn as she turns; quit the Park when she goes out, pass by her twice or thrice between that and St. Jame's; talk to her at night in the drawing Room—

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Before forty Coxcombs, and then the business is sufficiently proclaimed, is it not think you?

sp.speaker: Stan.
sp.p: Tis all one, it must be so, or you will pass for an old fashion d Lover, and never succeed beyond a Chamber-maid.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: This is a folly of our own growth, it came not to us out of France.

sp.speaker: Stan.
sp.p: That Nation ha's at this time no folly so harmless.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: But if there be any stirring of what kind soever, our empty young fellows will be sure to fill themselves with it, and prefer it to all the sence and good breeding of their own Countrey: But now we talk of France, I wonder we see not Carlos, he was expected from thence two or three nights since.

sp.speaker: Stan.
sp.p: See where he comes. Dear Carlos, I could not run more hastily upon my Mistress after a long absence; thou art the delight of all thy friends, and even thy Enemies take a malignant pleasure to behold that shape, that feature, and that meen.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Hold Stanmore, I think thou takes't me for a Mistress indeed by thy Complements, which I know not how to return.

sp.speaker: Stan.
sp.p: Thou art so improved, a man must love as I do, not to envy thee.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Enough Stanmore, your friendship blinds you, I never knew any of these loving Rogues good for any thing.
Bellamour, I am o'rejoy'd to see thee here, I heard thou had'st for sworn the Town.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Now I see Carlos here, methinks I am a perfect man of the Town again; I only forswore it for a time; 'Faith, Money is a thing gotten in ill Company, and spent in good; I have been laying up.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Men of War after a warm Engagement, must into the Docks to be new built for Fight.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Right, but how go matters in France? What new Foppery is turn'd up Trump there?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: What with Governors, Ladies eldest Sons, Embassadors and Envoyes, you have 'em here almost as soon as the French themselves.

sp.speaker: Stan.
sp.p: No alteration since we were there?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Wit and Women are quite out of Fashion, so are Flutes, Doux and Fidlers, Drums and Trumpets are their only Musick.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: 'Tis but ill Musick for their Neighbours.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: At home they are alwayes roaring out Te Deums for Stealing of some Town or other: War and Equipage is their discourse, which by the way is so Pompous, that should they conquer Europe they should scarce be savers.

sp.speaker: Stan.
sp.p: How came Wit and Women out of fashion?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Why in Camps they learn to live without Women; and for Wit, great men that love to play the fool in quiet, find it troublesome.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: 'Faith the latter of these is a great grievance here; our great men hate Wit, but love damn'd Flattery, though never so fulsom.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Pray what Fools does this Town afford?

sp.speaker: Stan.
sp.p: Very choice ones, we'l bring you where you shall enjoy 'em: there is a Widow lately come to Town who sets up for a great fortune, has taken a good House, and lives very splendidly, I suppose with intention to put off her self and two Daughters, who are very pretty, one of which Bellamour is in love with.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: I make love to her, I confess, but 'tis a harmless Lambent flame, and aimes but at fornication; but Stanmore is in love with the other, and Heaven knows what that may end in.

sp.speaker: Stan.
sp.p: I nave no designs upon her fortune, I aim only at her person, I yet run at the whole herd.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Come, you know your own tempers, no more in love then in play, where those who are very stingy at first, will bleed deeply at last.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p:
This Widow, by name the Lady Cheately, has made her House the Rendevouz of Fools, Knvaes, Whore-masters, Ladies of
all sorts, and young Heirs: Amongst the rest of Fops, there is Young Maggot, one whom his Uncle, whose Heir he is, bred at the Inns of Court, and intended for the Law, but he has left that, and is run Wit-mad; thinks of nothing, endeavours at nothing, but to be a Wit and a Lover, and both in spight of Nature.

sp.speaker: Stan.
sp.p: And though he has made Love and Wit his whole business, he is gotten no farther yet than to be thought a Wit by the Fools, and an Ass by the Witty men.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: This is a choice Spirit: Indeed 'tis a general Folly; for Wit is a common Idol that every Coxcomb worships in his heart, though some Blockheads of business dissemble it.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: But there is another Coxcomb of that extream vanity, that Nature amongst all her variety of Fops, has not produced the like: He draws all lines of Discourse to the center of his own Person, and never was known to speak, but I did, or I said, was at the beginning or end of it.

sp.speaker: Stan.
sp.p: He is lean as a Skeleton, and yet sets up for shape; he changed his Taylor twice, because his Shoulder-Bone sticks out.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: He thinks all Women in love with him, and all Men his intimate Friends; he will make doux oeux to a Judge upon the Bench, and not despair of getting a Widow at her Husband's Funeral; thinks himself very well bred, and welcome at all times to all People, though sober among Drunkards, and without a Penny in his Pocket to Men deep at Play.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Oh! I remember this Coxcomb, he has no fortune, and yet is always talking of Equipage and Dressing: 'Tis Selfish; but do any Women favour that Fop?

sp.speaker: Stan.
sp.p: Oh yes! There is no more account to be given of their Love before they know Man, than their longings after; but both are most commonly for nauseous nasty things.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: They do most things by chance; but when they chuse, 'tis ever for the worst.

sp.speaker: Foot.
sp.p: Mr. Selfish is combing his Peruque below stairs, and will be here instantly.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Retire while I show him.

div.stage: Enter Selfish; sets his Peruque, and bows to the Glass.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.p: How dost thou do, Bellamour? You fat Fellows have always Glasses that make one look so thin.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: You look in it much as you do out on't.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.p: Sure I am not so lean; I was told I look'd pretty plump to day: hah! my damn'd Rogue has put me into the most bustling Stuff; Bellamour, I like thy Breeches well.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Why you don't see▪ em.

sp.speaker: Self.
sp.p: Yes, I see 'em in the Glass; your Taylor shall make mine! a Pox on my Valet de Chambre, how he has tyed my Cravat up to day; a man cannot get a good Valet de Chambre, French or English.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: A French one is fittest for him, because he can fast best.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.p: I begin to Belly I think very much; I must go into France and flux, 'twill do my Complexion good as well as my Shape.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Why thou art fit to be hung up at Barber-Surgeons-Hall for a Skeleton; a Woman had as good lye with a Faggot.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.p: Thou art envious, the Ladies are of another mind; I am sure you are above Whore masters weight, and a Woman had as good lye with a pound of Candles.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Enough of this: There is a Friend of mine, one Carlos, lately come from France, that understands Dressing, I must bring you together.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.p: You talk of my Leanness: I had the most lucky Adventure; I was happy in the Conversation of a pretty Person of Quality, young and witty, I went in a Coach with my hand in her neck from the Duke's Play-house to the Pell-mell, kissing her all the way.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: There is a thing happen'd to me, in which I have occasion for your assistance and advice.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.p: I have lately succeeded in the Affections of so many pretty Creatures, faith, I know not how to turn my hands to 'em, poor Rogues; if you did but see the Advances that all the Ladies that come to the Widow's and her Daughters, make to me, you would stand amazed, and so should I, but that I am used to those things.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: This Fool is much improved since I went into France.

sp.speaker: Stan.
sp.p: Fools always improve in Folly, as witty men in Understanding.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Indeed he has great acquired Parts.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.p: Bellamour fare thee well, I must go home and answer two or three Billet doux from Persons of Quality, I have a bushel in a year. Adieu.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: A most admirable Coxcomb; he is so full of himself, he ne'r minds another man, and so answers quite from the purpose.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: He never answers any man 〈◊〉 cares to the answered, he desires but to be heard; but come Carlos let's take the air and while away a dineing time.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: I hate a Dinner, 'tis a good meal sor a dull plodding Fellow 〈◊〉 business that must bait like a Carriers Horse, and then to plodding again; but the Supper is the meal of pleasure and enjoyment.

sp.speaker: Stan.
sp.p: Supping indeed is a solemn thing, and should be used but with few, every Block head can Dine.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: That is, fill a Belly: but there are few men fit to Sup, there's more then eating requir'd for that mystery, there must be Wit and Sence.

sp.speaker: Yo. Mag.
sp.p: Your 〈◊〉 Gentlemen, I see Bellamour you are going abroad, I only come to show you my▪ last Verses.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Your last Verses, I would I could be so happy to see them.

sp.speaker: Yo. Mag.
sp.p: You have Company, and I have Business, some other time.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: What Business?

sp.speaker: Yo. Mag.
sp.p: Why, Wit and Beauty, I know no other, I am long'd for by the Ladies now to give account of the Play, for the Poets will not write, the Players Act, nor the Ladies censure without my Judgment first.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: The Ladies are indeed your finger Watches, that go just as you set them.

sp.speaker: Yo. Mag.
sp.p: Faith, that's very well imagin'd, well said, I think thou hast ne're as much Wit as one of us Writers.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: What is your opinion of the Play?

sp.speaker: Yo. Mag.
sp.p: I saw it Scene by Scene, and helped him in the writing, it breaks well, the Protasis good, the Catastasis excellent, there's no Episode, but the Catastrophe is admirable, I lent him that and the love parts, and the Songs. There are a great many sublimes that are very Poetical.

sp.speaker: Stan.
sp.p: Poetical, in his Judgment, is always Fustian and Nonsence in anothers, I warrant 'tis some Roring Ranting Play that's upon the fret all the while.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Will you carry us to a Rehearsal?

sp.speaker: Y. Mag.
sp.p: 'Tis a famaliarity among us Writers to see one another naked, you are men of Wit, and desperate Criticks, and we Poets fear you as singing Birds do a Hawk.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Thank you for your Hawk.

sp.speaker: Yo. Mag.
sp.p: Ay was it not well said?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: But methinks Fools should be your only Enemies.

sp.speaker: Yo. Mag.
sp.p: They can't hurt us, besides, a Dedication, writing Songs for their Mistresses, or showing them a Play before hand, will take them off.

sp.speaker: Foot.
sp.p: Sir, Mr. Prig is coming up.

sp.speaker: Y. Mag.
sp.p: Now shall we be troubled with Fools, a man can never enjoy thee half an hour to himself, thou art so haunted with Fops.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: How insupportable the Rogues are to one another.

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: What is this Prig?

sp.speaker: Stan.
sp.p: He is an universal Gamester, an admirable Horse and Dog Herauld, knows all the Remarkable ones, their Families, and Alliances, is indeed more intimately acquainted with Beasts, then Men; and 'tis fit he should be so.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: He is in short a Led-eater, Intelligencer, and dry-jester to Gameing, and Jocky-Lords; flatters, rooks, and passes for a Jolly Companion amongst 'em; and makes those things which are but the Recreations of men of Sence, his whole Business.

sp.speaker: Prig.
sp.p: Gentlemen good Morrow, tho I think 'tis almost Noon, where were you last Night? if you had been at my Lord Squanders, you had seen the best Play you had seen this Month. My Lord lost a Thousand pound, Jack Sharper won three Hundred. Tom Whiskin an Hundred, my Lord Whimsey lost five Hundred, Sir Thomas Rantipol lost six Hundred, Sir Nicholas Whachum won two Hundred, and the Rooks were very busie.

sp.speaker: Stan.
sp.p: Then you were not idle?

sp.speaker: Prig.
sp.p: No faith: But I am come to get you to look upon the best bred Horse in England. Woodcock was his Grandfather, he is the Son of Bay Lusty, and the Brother of Redrose; his Sister is the WhiteMare, the Cozen-german of Crack-a-fart, Cozen once removed to Nutmeg, third Cozen to my Lord Squanders Colt, ally'd to Flea-bitten by the second Venter; in short he is of an excellent Family, and I am going to make a civil Visit to him, he's to run for the Plate at Brackley, Stamford and Newmarket, and goes out of Town to Morrow.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: We cannot see him, we're ingaged.

sp.speaker: Prig.
sp.p:
Engag'd! no faith let's make a match at Tennis to day, I was invited to Dine by two or three Lords, but, if you will let me
have Pen, Ink and Paper, I'll send my dispatches, and dis-engage my self: How will that Gentleman and you play with Stanmore, and I keep his back hand at Gibbonses?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: I do not know his Play.

sp.speaker: Prigg.
sp.p: We'll take a Bisk of you.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: No, you shan't.

sp.speaker: Prigg.
sp.p: You'r half fifteen better than I to a Grain.

sp.speaker: Stanm.
sp.p: No, that he is not.

sp.speaker: Prigg.
sp.p: I never heard the like in my life; gad, you'll never let me make a reasonable Match with you; you beat Sharper at a Bisk, and he beats me; what will Stanmore and you give Maggot and me at White-hall, and play the best of your play? hah.

sp.speaker: Young Maggot.
sp.p: I never play, I stay at home and write.

sp.speaker: Prigg.
sp.p: Pish, 'tis all one for that, we'll play with you at a Bisk, and a fault, for twenty pound.

sp.speaker: You. Mag.
sp.p: I will not Sir.

sp.speaker: Prigg.
sp.p: Come, I'le hold you twenty pound, you do not make a fairer Match; Let me see— hold— anon— hum— ha— Ay— 'tis just so to a hairs breadth; Come, we'll play it.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: I tell you I am engag'd to day.

sp.speaker: Prigg.
sp.p: We'll play or pay to morrow at ten; where shall we sup?

sp.speaker: Stanm.
sp.p: No where, you cannot sup.

sp.speaker: Prigg.
sp.p: Not sup?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: No, you are not fit to sup.

sp.speaker: Prigg.
sp.p: No? I am sure I have as good a stomach, and will eat two meals a day with any man that wears a head.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: That will not do.

sp.speaker: Prigg.
sp.p: No? I'll eat three then; what say you Maggot, will you play?

sp.speaker: You. Mag.
sp.p: I will never play as long as I live, at that or any thing else, while I can have Pen, Ink and Paper.

sp.speaker: Prigg.
sp.p: O Lord! O Lord! I would not say so for all the world.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: A man must use Exercise to keep himself down, he will Belly else, and the Ladies will not like him.

sp.speaker: Young Magg.
sp.p: I have another way to bring down my Belly.

sp.speaker: Stanm.
sp.p: Another? What's that?

sp.speaker: Young. Magg.
sp.p: Why I study, I study and write; 'tis exercise of the Mind does it; I have none of the worst Shapes or Complexions, 'tis writing and inventing does my business.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Will that do't, Sir?

sp.speaker: Prigg.
sp.p: Think? What a Pox should a Gentleman think of but Dogs Horses, Dice, Tennis, Bowls, Races, or Cock-fighting? The Devil take me, I never think of any thing else, but now and then of a Whore (when I have a mind to her.)

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: This is strange, Mr. Maggot, and very curious; how do you know how much you fall away in a days time?

sp.speaker: Yo. Mag.
sp.p: I have an Engine to weigh my self when I sit down to write, or think; and when I unbend my self agen.

sp.speaker: Prigg.
sp.p: How do you unbend?

sp.speaker: Yo. Mag.
sp.p: Why I unbend my imagination, my intellect.

sp.speaker: Prigg.
sp.p: Your intellect, pray Sir what's that, is't a new word for a Cross-bow?

sp.speaker: Y. Mag.
sp.p: How I scorn Fops! Why I have been in love these two Months, and I have wasted above fourteen pound; Love is a great preserver of the shape, a very great one: You know my Mistress, the Widows youngest Daughter.

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: This is a curious Coxcomb.

sp.speaker: Prigg.
sp.p: Love! Ay, if a man gets a Clap, 'twill take him down.

sp.speaker: Yo. Mag.
sp.p: May it take down your Nose, you unthinking Animal.

sp.speaker: Prigg.
sp.p: What a Devil does he mean?

sp.speaker: Yo. Mag.
sp.p: Why I weigh'd my self, when I writ my last Song, and I wasted six ounces, aver du pois weight in the writing: And I was not above twelve hours about it.

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: I beseech you let's hear it Sir.

sp.speaker: Yo. Mag.
sp.p: Withal my heart.

lg.l: Damon see how charming Chloris,
Who gives love to all that see her,
Burning us yet in coldness glories,
And is never never freer.
Though darts and flames from her eye fly Sr.
And her Breast is warm and spicy,
Yet there is coldness in her eye Sr.
And her heart's all over Icy.
By coldness I am more inflamed,
As in Winter is Spring water,
My love by scorn can not be tamed,
But I the rather would be at her.

sp.speaker: Prigg.
sp.p: Did this make you waste six ounces? I writ a Song t'other day, and it did not make me waste at all.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Prithee Prigg let's hear it.

lg.l: ONE Night walking in a Wood,
I met one was a Maid as good
As e're she coud:
But she fired my Blood,
And to her I stood.
With a hey Boys, ding, ding, ding Boys hey,
With a hey Boys, ding, ding, ding.
Quoth I, my pretty Buxom Lass,
From me this time thou shalt not pass
In any Case;
For the sake of thy Face!
I'l lay thee on the Grass.
With a hey Boys, ding, &c.

sp.speaker: Yo. Mag.
sp.p: Oh what violence does he to my Ears,

sp.speaker: Prigg.
sp.p: What he does not like it? Pox! these Wits like nothing but what they do themselves, I love a Tavern Song, that will Roar, and make one Merry, a Pox of his Strephons and Phillises.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: What will become of you Young Maggot your Uncle Maggot? that common Foe to Wit, is coming up.

sp.speaker: Yo. Mag.
sp.p: Hide me Gentlemen, hide me, I am undone if he finds me in your Company.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Step in there.

sp.speaker: Magg.
sp.p: Gentlemen I come to look out an ungracious Nephew of mine, who I hear by virtue of your Company, sets up for a Wit: Will any of you keep him him when you have made him good for nothing.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Good for nothing▪ why, he is the darling of the Ladies, they dote on him for his Songs, and fear him for his Lampoons, and the men think no Debauch perfect without him.

sp.speaker: Magg.
sp.p: Yes, I hear he writ a Libel, I shall have him scrible away his ears, or write himself so far into the Ladies favours, to lose his Nose, or be knock'd o'th head; these are the fruits of Wit..

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: The disasters rather.

sp.speaker: Magg.
sp.p: The World will bear with you that have Estates, tho you have a little; but 'tis enough to undo a man that is to make his Fortune. My roguy Nephhew must leave Cook upon Littleton for Beaumont and Fletcher.

sp.speaker: Stan.
sp.p: Poetry is an ornament to a man of any profession.

sp.speaker: Magg.
sp.p: 'Tis a damn'd Weed, and will let nothing good or profitable grow by it, 'tis the Language of the Devil, and begun with Oracles. Where did you know a Wit thrive, or indeed keep his own?

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: They part with their Money for Pleasure, and Fools part with their Pleasure for Money; the one will make a better Last Will and Testament, but the other lead a happier Life.

sp.speaker: Y. Mag.

lg.l: Profit begone, what art thou but a breath.
I'l live proud of my Infamy and shame,
Grac'd with the Triumphs of a Poets name:
Men can but say, Wit did my Reason blind,
And Wit's the noblest srailty of the Mind.

sp.p: Methinks it runs well thus.

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.p: What noise is that? ha▪ My ungracious Nephew repeating Verses. Come out you Rascal; dost thou not tremble at my anger? Thou that mightest have been a Judge in time, to make a Wit of thy self thus!

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Good Sir be patient; Did not the great Pleader Cicero make Verses?

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.p: And you see what came on't, he died a Beggar, and of a violent death.

sp.speaker: Y. Mag.
sp.p: Sir, The Verses were not my own.

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.p: Sir, Be gone to the Temple, and let me once more find you at Wit, and I'll dis-inherit you.

sp.speaker: Y. Mag.
sp.p: Good Sir hear me.

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.p: Be gone, I say.

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: This is ridiculous enough, and odd.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: There is a powerful faction against Wit..

sp.speaker: Stan.
sp.p: Come, let's take the Air.

div.stage: Enter Lady Cheatly, and Mr. Lump her Brother.

sp.speaker: Lump.
sp.p: I see, Lady Sister, you are resolv'd to push on the remnant of your Estate, and make the Snuff of your Fortune burn clearest.

sp.speaker: L. Cheatly.
sp.p: As my Fortune was, it would do us no good; but this Town, and the way I take, may advance it, or at least dispose of my own Person.

sp.speaker: Lump.
sp.p: You shall not want my Money, so long as I have Deeds of Trust from you; you shall have the Name on't. I have help'd you to sober, solid, godly men, who will help to carry on your design.

sp.speaker: L. Cheatly.
sp.p: Some cautions old Fellow or other (who is wise enough to have his own Wisdom contribute to the cheating of him) may snap at me; and some rash, amorous, young Fellows may catch at my Daughters.

sp.speaker: Lump.
sp.p: I wish you had set up in the City among our Party, and gone to Meetings, it might have been a great advantage; I my self have made much benefit of Religion, as to my temporal Concerns, and (so long as it be directed to a good end) it is a pious fraud, and very lawful.

sp.speaker: L. Cheat.
sp.p: No Brother, The godly have two qualities, which would spoil my design; great Covetousness (which would make 'em pry too narrowly into our Fortune) and much Eating (which would too soon devour what I have left.)

sp.speaker: Lump.
sp.p: Reproach not the godly, Lady Sister, I do not like it.

sp.speaker: L. Cheat.
sp.p: Where is there a better Market for Beauty, than near the Court? And who will more likely snap at the shadow of a good Fortune, than the Gentlemen of this end of the Town, who are most of 'em in debt? And I have chosen the best Instrument in the world to make 'em believe me Rich.

sp.speaker: Lump.
sp.p: Who is that?

sp.speaker: L. Cheat.
sp.p: A very busie old Gentleman, and very credulous, that loves to tell News, and always magnifies a true Story till it becomes, a Lye, one Mr. Maggot.

sp.speaker: Lump.
sp.p: I know he is a Person of Parts, but he is not solid, he's hot-brain'd, and has not Method in him; for my own part, I think not▪ any one wise, who does not know what he shall do this day fifty years, if he lives; I for my part do.

sp.speaker: L. Cheat.
sp.p: I hope 'tis dining with me, Brother.

sp.speaker: Lump.
sp.p: No, Upon the one and twentieth of March, I shall fifty years hence, dine with Mr. Ananias Felt, an Elder of our Church, if we live, and he observe his Method; my Journal tells what I shall do each day of my lise.

sp.speaker: L. Cheat.
sp.p: Can you tell what you shall do next Midsummer-day fifty years?

sp.speaker: Lump.
sp.p: I shall go down to my House in Kent.

sp.speaker: L. Cheat.
sp.p: Do you never alter your Day?

sp.speaker: Lump.
sp.p: By no means; if one link of the Chain be broken, Wisdom falls to the ground.

sp.speaker: L. Cheat.
sp.p: What do you do upon the sixth of May come fifty year?

sp.speaker: Lump.
sp.p: This Book will tell you— May— May— 6th— 6th. Let me see— 6th— I take Physick, and shave my self.

sp.speaker: L. Cheat.
sp.p: What, sick or well, Beard or no Beard?

sp.speaker: Lump.
sp.p: 'Tis all one for that, I never break my Method— Let me see— the next day— I walk to Hampstead, Dine at the Queens-Head, Come back in my Coach, Visit Sr. Formall Trifle, and at night I do Communicate with my Wife.

sp.speaker: L. Cheat.
sp.p: Not fifty years hence; you'll go near to break that Method.

sp.speaker: Lump.
sp.p: I never break any— No man can be wise without this Principle— But Sister, I am to give you a main Caution; Have a care of Wits at this end of the Town; Wits are good for nothing, of no use in a Commonwealth, they understand not Business.

sp.speaker: L. Cheat.
sp.p: The better for my purpose. They value pleasure, and will bid high for't.

sp.speaker: Lump.
sp.p: I say they are good for nothing; they are not men of Method and Business.

sp.speaker: L. Cheat.
sp.p: So Fools say, who seem to be excellent men of Business, because they always make a business of what is none, and seem to be always very industrious, because they take great pains for what a witty man does with ease.

sp.speaker: Lump.
sp.p: You are out, you are out; hang 'em Wits, when did you see any of'em Rise?

sp.speaker: L. Cheat.
sp.p: No, Because the Fools are so numerous and strong, they keep 'em down; or rather because men of Wit (that have Fortunes) know what a senseless thing the drudgery of Business and Authority is, and those that have none, want the Impudence, Flattery, and Importunity of Blockheads.

sp.speaker: Lump.
sp.p: I fear you are tainted, vilely tainted with Wit; if you had fix'd in the City, you might have scap'd the Insection, no body would have put you in the head of Wit there. But hold, my hour is come— At three a Clock I will throw away a quarter of an hour upon you. Farewel.

sp.speaker: L. Cheat.
sp.p: Who waits there?
Oh my good Steward! Are the Scriveners come?

sp.speaker: Steward.
sp.p: Yes, Madam, Your design prospers beyond our hopes; it has taken fire like a train, and run through all the Town▪ and all believe you to be a great Fortune.

sp.speaker: L. Cheat.
sp.p: I have chosen as proper an Engine for my Business as can be, my Lady 〈◊〉, a perpetual Gossiper, and Visiter in all Families, a very wise Lady, a great Tattle and News Monger, who being 〈◊〉 too old sor an Intrigue of her own, is as good a body to help on those os others as can be, and is glad to bring Lovers of any kind together.

sp.speaker: Steward.
sp.p: Already the belief of your Wealth has spread so far, that I have had two of the 〈◊〉 this morning with me (who having been shrewdly bitten by 〈◊〉) are very desirous to trust their Money in your hands, hearing what Mortgages you have, and believing you can 〈◊〉 it better than any body.

sp.speaker: L. Cheat.
sp.p: You did not sure refuse 'em?

sp.speaker: Steward.
sp.p: No, I I'll warrant you, Madam, they will bring their Money presently; Mr. Maggot too entreats me, that I will be very importunate with your Ladyship, to imploy a thousand pound of his for him.

sp.speaker: L. Cheat.
sp.p: There needs no importunity, subtle Rogue; he thinks to lay it here for a 〈◊〉▪ and that I shall lay many more to it, which he hopes he may have again, together with my Person.

sp.speaker: Steward.
sp.p: No, Madam, Tis held in Mortmain, never to return again: Besides, we have Presents enough to keep your House this Moneth, brought in this Morning; A red Deer potted, a brace of fat Does, Hams of Bayon Bacon, a brace of Swans, potted Charrs, Brant Geese, and (besides all this) a piece of the best Wine in England. Here are the Names of the Presenters.

sp.speaker: L. Cheat.
sp.p: Let me see all Well-willers to my Self or Daughters: Cunning Fools; how very politiek they are? Well, Policy is most commonly the foolishest thing in the world.

sp.speaker: Steward.
sp.p: Madam, there are a great many waiting about money-business without, shall I call any of 'em in?

sp.speaker: L Cheat.
sp.p: By no means— when I am alone: when Company is with me, they are of use, and spread my fame abroad: Entertain 'em well, and bid 'em hasten Dinner.

div.trailer: The End of the First Act.

div.head: ACT II.
div.stage: Enter Lady Cheatly and Lady Busy.

sp.speaker: L. Cheat.
sp.p: MAadm I am infinitely oblig'd to your Ladyship, who can be so careful of my whole Family.

sp.speaker: L. Busy.
sp.p: Why truly Madam I love to do good Offices, we are bound in Christian Charity to one another, and I wish'd Mr. Maggot to your Ladyship, if he be not somewhat too old for the Vigour of your Ladyship: he is rich, and is discreet, and his other Defects may be supplied elsewhere.

sp.speaker: L. Cheat.
sp.p: Your Ladyship's very obliging.

sp.speaker: L. Busy.
sp.p: If not, there's Mr. Prigg, an ingenious Gentleman, of a pretty Fortune, whom I wish'd to you; he is in great favour with Lords, I warrant you, you shall seldom take him without a Lord in his mouth, they do so court him, they love him mightily.

sp.speaker: L. Cheat.
sp.p: And he loves Lords mightily for being so.

sp.speaker: L. Busy.
sp.p: Oh mightily! Well Madam, your two Daughters are accounted the Beauties of the Drawing Room; there's no body while they there, will vouchsafe to look upon a Maid of Honour, no, not they, and they are as mad at it.

sp.speaker: L. Cheat.
sp.p: 'Tis not the Beauty of my Daughters makes▪ em look at 'em so, but they like an indifferent new face better than those faces they are used to every Night. They are weary of 'em.

sp.speaker: L. Busy.
sp.p: Oh, no really your Daughters are the prettiest Creatures in Town, and I would fain have 'em well settled, one way or other; I have had several offers of Husbands for 'em, but I do not think I have yet met with Fortunes good enough; but that great Lord I told you of, is very pressing to enjoy your Eldest, and as I said, he offers a Thousand pounds down, and three Hundred pound per Annum during life; but that I know your Ladyship is discreet, and one that has seen the World, I dar'd not have propounded this to you.

sp.speaker: L. Cheat.
sp.p: My Daughters have Fortunes enough to Marry 'em to good Estates, but your Ladyship is wise, 'tis good to treat with all persons, and all ways, to settle a young— Girl in the World.

sp.speaker: L. Busy.
sp.p: Why Madam this will be a great Addition to her Fortune, and besides you do not know how he may prefer her, or for ought we know, after he has try'd her, he may like her so well as to own her— who knows? Be pleas'd to consider how Marriage is cry'd down, and that there are few that are good for any thing will think on't now adays: besides, Custom alters all things mightily— Mothers very frequently do this for their Daughters now, and if it be a fashion you know—

sp.speaker: L. Cheat.
sp.p:
I am very much oblig'd to your Ladyships advice, I have propounded it to my Daughter, but she is so perverse, she will not
listen to me, but says she had rather Marrya Groom, than be Mistress to a Prince.

sp.speaker: L. Busy.
sp.p: Oh fy, she has a wrong Notion of the thing, I will try to advise her better.

sp.speaker: L. Cheat.
sp.p: Your Ladyship will do me a great favour, here they come both.

sp.speaker: L. Busie.
sp.p: Ladies, your Servant.

sp.speaker: Isab. Gart.
sp.p: Your Ladyships most humble Servant.

sp.speaker: L. Busie.
sp.p: Mrs. Isabella, I have something to advise you for your good.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: For my good, Madam?

sp.speaker: L. Busie.
sp.p: Yes, Madam, and therefore be pleased to give attention to me.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: Good Manners will make me do that.

sp.speaker: L. Busie.
sp.p: Why look you, You are young, I am in years, an ancient Woman, and have seen the World, as they say.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: Ancient? Your Ladyship looks very youthfully.

sp.speaker: L. Busie.
sp.p: No, no, You are pleased to Complement me; but, as I said, my Lady and my Self have known the World, as the saying is.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: And you the Flesh, and the Devil, as the saying is.

sp.speaker: L. Busie.
sp.p: And tis sit the Young should submit themselves to the gravity and discretion of the Old.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: Yes, where they can find it.

sp.speaker: L. Busie.
sp.p: Go to— My Lady is a Person whose aim is to settle you well in the World— Do you conceive me— And she knows what's sittest and most convenient for you— And Obedience is the best Vertue.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: Very well, Madam.

sp.speaker: L. Busie.
sp.p: Now there is a certain Lord, whom my Lady has mentioned to you.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: A Lord? a Beast, and one that would make me as bad as himself.

sp.speaker: L. Cheat.
sp.p: Good Mrs. Pert, Keep in that foolish Instrument, your Tongue: A Beast? there are a great many like him.

sp.speaker: L. Busie.
sp.p:
Be not so forward, all things have two Faces— Do not look upon the wrong one— Go to— You are a fine young Lady, and are brought by your Lady Mother to Town, the general Mart
for Beauty. Well— you would be so setled in the World, as to have a certain Fond, whereon you may rely, which in Age may secure you from Contempt— Good.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: I hope I shall have enough to keep me honest.

sp.speaker: L. Busiy.
sp.p: Nay, Heaven forbid I should persuade you to be dishonest: Vertue is a rare thing, a heavenly thing. But I say still, be mindful of the main— alass a Woman is a solitary, helpless Creature without a Man, God knows— good— how may this Man be had in Marriage say you?— very well— if you could get a fine Gentleman with Money enough, but alas! those do not Marry, they have left it off. The Customes of the World change in all Ages.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: In ours for the worse.

sp.speaker: L. Busy.
sp.p: Very well said,— but yet the wisest must obey 'em as they change,— do you conceive, Madam.—

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: Yes, I do conceive you to be doing a very Reverend Office.

sp.speaker: Gart.
sp.p: Methinks her Ladyship speaks a great deal of Reason, she's a a fine spoken Lady truly.—

sp.speaker: L. Busy.
sp.p: Now I say since Custom has so run down Wedlock, what remains? but that we should make use of the next think to it— good— Nay, not but that Vertue is a rare thing,— Heaven forbid I should detract from that;— But, I say, the main is to be respected, a good deal of Money, there's the point.—

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: With little or no Reputation,— there's the point.

sp.speaker: L. Cheat.
sp.p: Money brings Reputation, Fool, or at least puts one into that Condition, that Fellows dare not question it.

sp.speaker: L. Busy.
sp.p: Nay Heaven forbid you should lose that, but I say the next thing to Marriage, is being kind to a noble Lord, &c. And if good terms be made, and you be well settled in the World.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: That would be to be settled out of the World: for I should never dare to shew my face again.

sp.speaker: L. Cheat.
sp.p: There are as good faces as yours, and better, my nimble Chaps, that are shown every day in the Play-house, after it, and with the best quality too.

sp.speaker: L. Busy.
sp.p: Yes, and in the front of Boxes,— nay, nay, not but that a good Wealthy Marriage is beyond it.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: A very Comfortable thing, for a Gentlewoman to bring her self into a Condition of never conversing with a Woman of Quality, who has Wit, and Honour, again; but must sort with those Tawdry painted things of the Town.

sp.speaker: Gart.
sp.p: Can't you keep Company with my Mother and me.

sp.speaker: L. Busy.
sp.p: Look you Madam, you are under a great mistake, for do not Ladies of Wit and Honour, keep dayly Company with those things as you call them? But de'e conceive me, the finest things,— the gayest things,— and some the richest things, I say no more, I pray conceive me, as long as you are true to one Man, Madam, you are in a manner his Lady, I say in a manner his Lady, 'tis a kind of Marriage, and great Persons most commonly cohabit longer with Mistresses, than they used to do with Wives.

sp.speaker: L. Cheat.
sp.p: My Lady says right, 'tis, now adays, more like Marriage than Marriage it self.

sp.speaker: Gart.
sp.p: Oh Sister! do what my Lady says, she's a rare person.

sp.speaker: L. Busy.
sp.p: A Thousand pound, and three Hundred pound per Annum, say we bring him to four Hundred pound, good— a great Lord— that is in the way to prefer you, very good— or may be, may like you so well, as to own you— best of all; consider, 'tis enough, Madam, at once, let her ruminate upon this.

sp.speaker: Gart.
sp.p: O Lord, pray Sister do; why, we shall be all made, prithee do.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: Go you to your Mr. Maggot that Dyes, and makes Songs for you.

sp.speaker: Gart.
sp.p: No, I'l swear he's a fine witty person, but he has such a greivous face, I can't abide it; but there's Mr. Selfish is the most gentile, well-bred Gentleman, and has the finest ways among Ladies; he will tell you such pretty things of himself, he talks of himself always so prettily, and says such neat, gentile, well-bred things to one.

sp.speaker: Stew.
sp.p: Madam, some Gentlemen are coming in.

sp.speaker: L. Cheat.
sp.p: Bid the Scriveners and the rest of the people come in, Daughters go, and walk in the Garden: I hope your Ladiship will pardon me, this Money-business must be minded.

sp.speaker: L. Busy.
sp.p: By all means, Madam: I'l go make a Visit; your Servant.

sp.speaker: Scriv.
sp.p: I have brought the Mortgage, and the Mortgager is here ready to seal, upon the payment of the within named Sum.

sp.speaker: L. Cheat.
sp.p: Has my Councel perused it?

sp.speaker: Councel.
sp.p: Yes, and find it to be very well drawn.

sp.speaker: L. Cheat.
sp.p: Let me read it.

div.stage: Enter Stanmore, Bellamour, Carlos and Maggot.

sp.speaker: Steward.
sp.p: The Company is come.

sp.speaker: L. Cheat.
sp.p: Peace, I see 'em.

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.p: Look you, did I not tell you, she's always thus busie; I warrant upon a Mortgage, or a Purchase; she's a vast Fortune, I know where her Money lies, and in what hands; she has a vast deal, do not interrupt her, you shall hear.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Then you know all?

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.p: Know all, ay why, Sir William, her late Husband, was my intimate friend: Know, why, I hired this House, and bought all the Furniture for her; her Daughters will be worth ten Thousand pound apeice, at least, to my knowledge.

sp.speaker: Stan.
sp.p: This Fellow will outly any Traveller.

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.p: I knew her Father as well as any man in the World; know, why, I know all.

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: This Lady must be a Cheat, by doing her business so publickly.

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.p: Mr. Carlos, I knew your Father as well as any man in England: honest James, his Keeper! I have had many a Buck of him.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Did you know my Father?

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.p: Did I? no flesh alive better, I did more for him, than any man in England, I was a Father to him.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Ay! then you are my Grandfather; but how were you a Father to him?

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.p: How? Why I gave him his second Wife.
To have and to hold.

sp.speaker: L. Cheat.
sp.p: 'Tis very well; five thousand pound is the sum; Steward, pay him the Money, and take the Writings.

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.p: Look you there, did not I tell you?

sp.speaker: 1 Citizen.
sp.p: Well, She's a rare Woman at Business.

sp.speaker: 2 Citizen.
sp.p: As ever I saw.

sp.speaker: Stev.
sp.p: Here are the two Gentlemen I spoke of, who humbly desire to place some Money in your Ladyships hands.

sp.speaker: L. Cheat.
sp.p: I do not love to meddle with other People's Money, you know; besides, I shall have no occasion. I have a great sum to be paid in within this Fortnight.

sp.speaker: Stew.
sp.p: I know it, Madam, but if a Purchase should be offered in the mean time.

sp.speaker: 1 Citiz.
sp.p: I beseech your Ladyship, take our Money, we have been so cheated by base Goldsmiths, we are afraid to trust any body but your Ladyship.

sp.speaker: L. Cheat.
sp.p: I do not love to stand charged for other People's Money. Oh me Gentlemen! I was so busie I did not see you, you have not waited long, I hope; pray forgive my Rudeness.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: The Rudeness is on our side, to intrude into your Ladyships Privacies.

sp.speaker: L. Cheat.
sp.p: By no means; you do me Honour.

sp.speaker: Stan.
sp.p: Madam, We take the liberty to present Mr. Carlos, a Friend of ours, lately come out of France, to your Ladyship?

sp.speaker: L. Cheat.
sp.p: Sir, I have heard of your Noble Family, and you'll honour mine in your acquaintance with it. Sweet Mr. Maggot; your Servant: Gentlemen, Have but a little patience, till I have dispatch'd some Business, and I'll wait on you.

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.p: God, She's the finest Person in the World, and a vast Fortune; I wou'd my ungracious Nephew had one of her Daughters.

sp.speaker: Prigg.
sp.p: Madam, Your most humble Servant.

sp.speaker: L. Cheat.
sp.p: Your Servant, sweet Mr. Prigg.

sp.speaker: Prigg.
sp.p: Sweet Mr. Prigg! good; Matters go on well: Come, Gentlemen, since my Lady▪ s busie, let's go to Langtriloo, or Ombre.

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: Is there no way of spending our time but playing?

sp.speaker: Prigg.
sp.p: None so good: Why what a Pox should one do?

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: Read; it is a manly Diversion.

sp.speaker: Prigg.
sp.p: Read? So I have read Markham, The Compleat Farrier, and two or three Books about Horses; a Book that's written about Ombre, and that about Picket; and for other Books, Pox there's nothing in 'em at all: What think you, Bellamore?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: You are in the Right.

sp.speaker: Prigg.
sp.p: Look you there, there's nothing in 'em, hah.

sp.speaker: Stan.
sp.p: Methinks Discourse is a pretty good way of passing ones time.

sp.speaker: Prigg.
sp.p: Gad, So it is: I talk as much as any Man in England, my Tongue seldom lyes still; Oh! I love Discourse mightily; and though I say it, I am able to run down all I meet about Dogs and Horses. Now I think on't, Have you ever hunted with my Lord, Squande'rs Fox-Dogs, Bellamore?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: No: Now he's in.

sp.speaker: Prigg.
sp.p: They are the best in England; but there is one Dog we call Ranter, I Christned him, I was his God-Father; he was gotten upon my Lord's famous Bitch-Lady; you remember what a Bitch she was; Oh poor Lady! I was not sorryer when my Sister died, than when poor Lady died. But let that pass; Ranter was gotten by your Father's Dog, Rockwood.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Did you know Rockwood?

sp.speaker: Prigg.
sp.p: Know him? As well as any Man in the World; his Father was a Dog of my Father's, called Jowler; his Mother was my Noble Lord Squanders Father's famous Bitch▪ Venus, which you have heard of: I remember, Mr. Carlos Venus was Sister to your Father's Dog Ringwood; Rockwood? I knew him as well as I knew your Father, well rest their Souls of a Dog and a Man, I shall never see two better in the Field than Rockwood and your Father.

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: How the Rogue has coupled them.

sp.speaker: Prigg.
sp.p: Yet Ranter's an admirable Dog, the best at a cold Scent that ever I saw; if there be forty Couple in the Field, I'll hold an hundred pound he works it out soonest, and leads 'em all when he has done. I love and honour Ranter, I care not who knows it; I made a Song of him, have his Picture by my Bed-side, and some of his Hair here in a crystal Locket.

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.p: I beseech your Ladyship, Accept of my thousand pound, 'twill make up the Money for that Purchase, sweet Madam.

sp.speaker: L. Cheat.
sp.p: Well, Sir, Since you will have it so, I'll give my Bond for it.

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.p: Oh Madam! I scorn it, I'll have nothing under Hand for it.

sp.speaker: L. Cheat.
sp.p: Then I will not take it; nay, I have sworn first.

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.p: Well, I'll go and fetch it, and your Ladyship and I will agree upon that.

sp.speaker: Prigg.
sp.p: Ha! The young Ladies are in the Garden.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Say you so? Prithee let's steal down to 'em.

sp.speaker: Prigg.
sp.p: Do, and leave me with the Widow.

sp.speaker: L. Cheat.
sp.p: Steward, Do you take care of all the rest, while I retire from (what I do not care for) Business. Now I am at leisure; Are the Gentlemen gone?

sp.speaker: Prigg.
sp.p:
They are gone but into the Garden, and will wait on your Ladyship presently. They have left me that happy opportunity I wish'd for, to renew the Suit I have so often made to your Ladyship;
I beseech you, Madam, be pleas'd to consider my Passion, which is so violent to your Ladyship, I cannot rest since first I saw your Ladyship; for it has indeed put me besides my self. I have not the heart to ride so much as one heat at New-Market since, and I used to go once in ten days down on purpose; nor have I been able to ride a Fox-Chase, since I have had your Ladyship in chace; I shall be undone, if your La'ship don't quiet my mind with some assurances: I over-see at Trick track, dealt my self ten at Ombre, and all through my Passion for your dear Self.

sp.speaker: L. Cheat.
sp.p: Sir, Though I have a great esteem for your Person, yet we Widows that have some Fortune, are to consider something besides Passion.

sp.speaker: Prigg.
sp.p: As I have told you before, my Estate is not inconsiderable, besides the great Favour I have with the Gameing and Jocky Lords; and besides, if the King frequents New-Market, I doubt not but in a short time to Rise.

sp.speaker: L. Cheat.
sp.p: But you are a Gamester.

sp.speaker: Prigg.
sp.p: Ay Madam, but I never Play, I do but Rook.

sp.speaker: L. Cheat.
sp.p: Rook? What's that? Cheat?

sp.speaker: Prigg.
sp.p: No, Madam, I go to Twelve, and the better of the Lay; besides, I get five hundred pound a year at Horse-Races, and Cock-Matches, by being in fee with the Grooms, and Cock-keepers; and, Madam, I play as well at Tennis, Ombre, Back-gammon, Trick track, and Crimp, as any Man, which is no small addition to my Estate. I gave you these things in my particular, if your Ladyship please to remember.

sp.speaker: L. Cheat.
sp.p: But you cannot make a Joynture of these things, and therefore I must consider a little longer.

sp.speaker: Prigg.
sp.p: With all my heart, Madam; but in the mean time let you and I play a Set at Trick track, and when the rest come in, well make a Match at Ombre.

sp.speaker: Stew.
sp.p: Madam, There are some Tenants wait without to speak with you.

sp.speaker: L. Cheat.
sp.p: You'll pardon me, I must go to 'em.

sp.speaker: Prigg.
sp.p: Come on, Mr. Steward, what say you to a Game at Back-gammon?

sp.speaker: Stew.
sp.p: If you'll retire to my Chamber, have at you.

sp.speaker: Prigg.
sp.p: With all my heart.

div.stage: Enter Theodosia, Isabella, Bellamour, Carlos, Stanmore.

sp.speaker: Carlos.
sp.p: Who's there, the Lady Pleasant's Daughter, Theodosia?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: It is: She's young and handsom, has a great deal of Wit, and a very good Fortune, which makes her set up for Marriage, and is impregnable to any thing else.

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: She's extream pretty; I lov'd her violently, before I went into France, but now she's a Thousand times more Beautiful.

sp.speaker: Stanm.
sp.p: Ladies, your humble Servant.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: A Gentleman, a friend of ours, lately come out of France.

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: And glad I am so, for all that Nation could not shew me so much Beauty.

sp.speaker: Theod.
sp.p: I see, Sir, you have not been in France for nothing; you have imported French goods, I mean Compliments, they are a Nation full of Complimenters.

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: They are so, Madam; and the Taylor does it full as well as the Gentleman, 'tis a Road of speaking which all of 'em have, I was not dull enough to get it of 'em, nor would I bring so common a thing as a Compliment to you, Madam.

sp.speaker: Theod.
sp.p: You can bring it to no Body that dislikes it more.

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: Or needs it less.

sp.speaker: Theod.
sp.p: Thus have I heard of a very Rhetorical Oration against Eloquence.

sp.speaker: Gart.
sp.p: O'Lord, Mr. Stanmore, here.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Run Stanmore, your business is more than half done; 'tis a certain sign, when a Woman seeks Corners, that she means some good by it.

sp.speaker: Stanm.
sp.p: I'l try that.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: I see my friend's caught again, for all his Travel; I have a fellow-feeling of his Case, let's retire and give him opportunity.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: With all my heart, opportunity is safe in the beginning of an Amour, though it may be dangerous afterwards.

sp.speaker: Theod.
sp.p: I hear never a French word from you, and that's strange: for all our Sparks are so refined, they scarce speak a sentence without one; and though they seldome arrive at good French, yet they get enough to spoil their English.

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: If a man means nothing, he cannot chuse a better Language▪ for it makes a pretty noise, without any manner of thought.

sp.speaker: Theod.
sp.p: You have scarce brought one substantial Vanitie over with you, what have you learnt there?

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: To love my own Countrey, and to think that none can show us so fine Women; in France they buy their Beauty, and sell their Love.

sp.speaker: Theod.
sp.p: That Fashion is coming up apace here.

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: True Beauty, Madam, can no more be bought than true Love; in me behold the one, while I admire the other in your self.

sp.speaker: Theod,
sp.p: How many French Ladies have you said as much to?

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: I went thither to be cured of Love, not to make it.

sp.speaker: Theod.
sp.p: What Love?

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: My love of you, which began so early in my Heart, self-love was scarce before it. When your disdain could not remove it; I tried absence, but in vain too.

sp.speaker: Theod.
sp.p: Tis impossible you could bring a Heart unhurt from France.

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: My Love to you preserved me from all Foreign Invasion.

sp.speaker: Theod.
sp.p: If you make Love, you'l grow dull, it spoils a man of Wit, as much as Business.

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: If Love be predominant in Conversation, I confess it, but a little relish of it does well.

sp.speaker: Theod.
sp.p: The imitation of it may be borne, but the thing its self is a dead weight upon the mind; and a man can no more please under that disadvantage, than a Horse can run a Race with a pair of Panniers on his Back.

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: And yet that Horse may do it, if the match be well made.

sp.speaker: Theod.
sp.p: I must have my Servant all Wit, all Gaiety, and the Ladies of the Town run mad for him: I would not only triumph over him, but over my whole Sex in him.

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: This is hard Doctrine for a man of my sincerity and truth in Love.

sp.speaker: Theod.
sp.p: Make Isabella slight Bellamour, little Gartrude sacrifice Selfish: Be the third word in every Ladies mouth, from fifteen to five and thirty; and you shall find what I'l say to you.

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: To attempt this, were great vanity, and no less dishonesty, to my friend Bellamour.

sp.speaker: Theod.
sp.p: If you love, you'l think any thing lawful: This must be done, I dare not trust my own judgment; I will have you in vogue, e're I favour you in the least.

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p:
Well, since these Ladies are your outworks, I will on, and
by the force of imagination, make every one Theodosia, but if I fail, think on my constant love, which will not suffer me to use deceit.

sp.speaker: Theod.
sp.p: Suppose I should answer you in your whining strein, and say, my love were true as yours, my flame as great, and all your wishes mine.

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: Then were Carlos the happiest man on Earth.

sp.speaker: Theod.
sp.p: No, then the Game were up betwixt us, and there were no more to do but to pay the stakes, and then to something else.

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: We might play Set after Set for ever.

sp.speaker: Theod.
sp.p: No, one of us would be broke; go get you about your task I say.

sp.speaker: Yo. Mag.
sp.p: Did you see how the Ladies flockt about me at Court, when I made a relation of the Rehearsal, and afterwards when I read my Song to 'em.

sp.speaker: Self.
sp.p: I think I am as well with the Ladies there as any Man, and they like my Songs too, they say they'r so easie, so gentile, and well bred, and so pat to the Womens understandings: the Men say th'are silly, but they are envious.

sp.speaker: Yo. Mag.
sp.p: I'l secure you the Play takes, I have done the Poet's business with the Ladies, who, you know govern the Men, as the Moon does the Sea.

sp.speaker: Self.
sp.p: There is a pretty Creature, not past Eighteen, whom I have formerly enjoy'd, has to oblige me, taken upon her the figure of a procurer, and is to bring me a maidenhead anon, which fell in love with me at a Play.

sp.speaker: Yo. Mag.
sp.p: But I'l shew you my Song.

sp.speaker: Self.
sp.p: Of late I have had no leisure to make a Song, I am so over-run with new Acquaintances.

sp.speaker: Yo. Mag.
sp.p: Damon see how charming Chloris, &c.
How do you like it?

sp.speaker: Self.
sp.p: 'Tis soft, and very much after my own way, and I like it well. But how like you this Peruque?

sp.speaker: Yo. Mag.
sp.p: 'Tis very proper.

sp.speaker: Self.
sp.p: I have five as good by me, I have an hundred pound I got at Ombre, Mr. Whimsey ows me two hundred, I have a Pad or two, and when I get this debt in, I will buy a Chariot, and perhaps have as good Equipage as any Man, if I can get an hundred pound Sir Nicholas Whachum ows me; I only want a couple of Hunters for Windsor, and then.

sp.speaker: Yo. Mag.
sp.p: You don't mind my Song, 'tis to my Mistress. '

sp.speaker: Self.
sp.p: Yes, but I was saying, now I am at ease in my Fortune till next Michlemas.

sp.speaker: Yo. Mag.
sp.p: But to go on.

sp.speaker: Self.
sp.p: I have lately got such a Conquest over a Lady, the prettiest Creature; I snatch'd a Rose from her soft Bosom, she is of quality, all the Town were mad after her, and she threw her self into my Arms, and I am the happy Man.

sp.speaker: Yo. Mag.
sp.p: Well, to be in love is the greatest pleasure in the World, it makes one so sweetly Malancholly, and Composed, and so fit to write; besides, it keeps one in shape.

sp.speaker: Self.
sp.p: I have not much occasion for Love, the Ladies follow me and love me so, I have no time for't, why, I have had three Maiden-heads this week.

sp.speaker: Yo. Mag.
sp.p: I would not be without love, and writing, for all the World; I had a Billet from the prettiest Creature of Sixteen to Day, I'l tell you.

div.stage: Enter Carlos, Bellamore, Theodosia and Isabella.

sp.speaker: Yo. Mag.
sp.p: I have an Amour.

sp.speaker: Self.
sp.p: I.

sp.speaker: Yo. Mag.
sp.p: I.

sp.speaker: Self.
sp.p: I.

sp.speaker: Yo. Mag.
sp.p: I.

sp.speaker: Self.
sp.p: This Fellow is always talking of himself, one can't speak to him, bus he is always at I, I. I wonder at the impertinence of such people.

sp.speaker: Theod,
sp.p: These Fools are always talking of themselves.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: They are the worst things they can talk of.

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: Or we either; therefore, Madam, hear me on the last Subject.

sp.speaker: Theod.
sp.p: That's as bad.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: He went a Mile to put on that fair Peruque, for the sake of his Complexion.

sp.speaker: Theod.
sp.p: Prithee Isabella let's find fault with em both, and break his heart.

sp.speaker: Gert.
sp.p: Fy upon you Mr. Stanmore; I'l ne're come near you agen, if you use me so, you nothing but kiss one, and ruffle one, and spoils one things, that you do.

sp.speaker: Stan.
sp.p: Why are you so pretty then, to provoke a man beyond all patience?

sp.speaker: Gart.
sp.p: Why, how do I provoke you? I have done nothing to anger you, have I?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: What are you fallen out with your Mistress?

sp.speaker: Stan.
sp.p: No, but since she's insensible of all, I can speak to her, and yet so pretty, I cannot but love her; if words won't move her, actions must.

sp.speaker: Self.
sp.p: Oh! here are the Ladies; now you shall see what Advances they will make to me, but especially Gartrude, that pretty Creature.

sp.speaker: Yo. Mag.
sp.p: This is a very conceited Fellow, and wou'd call a Gypsee that lik'd him, pretty Creature.

sp.speaker: Self.
sp.p: Ladies, your most humble Servant; now you shall see Maggot, dear pretty Creature, let me kiss that Nosegay; well, 'tis a Thousand times sweeter in that pretty Bosom, than in its own Bed, though at the Sun rising, when the Morning Dew is in drops upon it, sweet Madam, let me kiss that hand that gather'd it.

sp.speaker: Gart.
sp.p: Oh fine, what rare words are these! He uses me like a Princess: Sir, 'tis more your goodness, then my desert. Sister, this is a rare man, Mr. Stanmore is a Wit they say, but I don't understand him half so well, I always think they Jeer one.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: Indeed 'tis a hard thing for Wit to descend to your Capacity.

sp.speaker: Self.
sp.p: I was with some Ladies last Night did so commend you, and said you were the most delicate Creature; they did me the favour to say your Eyes were black, and sparkling like mine, and your Nose very much resembling mine, and that you have a pretty pouting about the mouth like me, and fine little blub-lips, I am very well with the Ladies at Court, but I see none like you.

sp.speaker: Stan.
sp.p: Do you know I love that Lady?

sp.speaker: Self.
sp.p: If you do, I pitty you, she is otherwise engaged to my knowledge.

sp.speaker: Prig.
sp.p: Come, faith, since we are all together, let's go to Ombre, two Companies, and make an Afternoon on t.

sp.speaker: Yo. Mag.
sp.p: I desire you will not interrupt me; I am singing the Ladies a new Song.

sp.speaker: Prig.
sp.p: Song? Pish, Is not Gaming better than hearing of Songs? here's such a stir with these Wits.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: No, pray let's hear it.

sp.speaker: Prig.
sp.p:
I observe you Wits are always making Songs of the Love of Shepherds, and Shepherdesses, a company of block-headed, clownish,
ugly, tawny, Sun-burnt People; I had e'en as live hear Songs upon the Love of their Sheep as their own.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: I see these Fools need no body to shew 'em, they shew themselves well enough.

sp.speaker: Prig.
sp.p: Methinks that old Song is very pretty: My Mistress is a Tennis Ball, &c.

sp.speaker: Yo. Mag.
sp.p: This Rogue has nothing but Tennis Courts and Bowling-Greens in his Head.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Prithee Prigg sing one of your own making.

sp.speaker: Prig.
sp.p: With all my heart.

sp.speaker: L. Cheat.
sp.p: Mrs. Theodosia, your humble Servant: Gentlemen, I hope you'll pardon me, I could not neglect Business; I think one had better be poor, than be troubled with Money thus: But if you please to walk in, there's a small Banquet waits, and Fiddles, to dance, if you please.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: Pray, Madam, let's hear Mr. Prigg's Song first, 'tis his own.

sp.speaker: Prig.
sp.p: I am glad your Ladyship is come to hear it.

lg.l: Hey ho, hey ho,
The merry Horn does blow.
'Tis broad day,
Come away.
Twivee, twivee, twivee, hey,
Do not stay.
Then have at the Hare,
Let old Puss beware.
Twivee, twivee, twivee, ho,
The merry Horn does blow.
Come away.

sp.speaker: Yo. Mag.
sp.p: What a happy thing 'tis to have Wit..

sp.speaker: Prig.
sp.p: Hang Wit, give me Mirth. This is a Catch that I made, and my Lord Squander and I always roar it out after a Fox Chase; Pox, I hate your Swains and your Nymphs.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.p: Do they wear Breeches thus out in Prance?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Yes, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.p: What Blockheads are our English Taylors; I must have some new Cloaths made immediately in this Fashion, I cannot rest till I bespoak 'em.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: Pray, Madam, joyn with us, we shall have very good sport. Are you well, Mr. Selfish? Sure you are not, I never saw you look so ill before.

sp.speaker: Theod.
sp.p: He looks extream ill; your Complexion seems tohav e too much of the Olive in it to day.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.p: Pardon me, Ladies, I think my Complexion is well enough, or my Glass is false, I never lookt clearer.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: That Trimming too, with your favour, is very dis-agreeable, and does not cohere with your Complexion at all.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.p: I assure you, Sir, all the Ladies I saw to day, are of another opinion, they said, my Complexion was much like pretty Mrs. Gartrudes here.

sp.speaker: L. Cheat.
sp.p: Methinks you look mighty lean and thin, I fear you are going into a Consumption, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.p: Oh no, Madam! I am very plump, I am only afraid of being too gross, and bellying; I am very fat, I assure your Ladyship, pray feel my Ribs, Madam.

sp.speaker: Prig.
sp.p: They laugh at him. The Devil take me, I never saw a Fellow so altered in my life; thou canst not live long, thou smell'st of Earth, foh.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.p: You mistake, I am one of the vigourest Fellows, the strongest Bodies in England; I was taken for Mr. Carlos to day at a little distance.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Prithee Selfish do not play the fool with thy self, get a Physician, I never saw your Complexion so sallow, thou look'st prodigiously ill.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.p: Good Sir, I know what I am; my Cheeks are as plump, and my Complexion as fresh as any here, my Eyes and Mouth as chearful, and every thing.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Nothing will mortifie the Rogue; he thinks so well of Selfish, that he thinks Selfish can never look ill, nor be ill, I believe he thinks Selfish can never die.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.p: I have a Face that will not alter, if I were a dying, 'twould look well; indeed my Complexion changes sometimes, but never looks ill, I assure you.

sp.speaker: Gart.
sp.p: I wonder you should be so mistaken all, methinks he looks very neatly.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: This is a damn'd Perruque, why did you put it on, to day?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: But indeed that Suit is an odious thing, and the Trimming the worst I ever saw; tis your Taylor's 〈◊〉 〈◊〉 you very ill.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.p: Methinks it is very pretty, I think they are all out of their wits.

sp.speaker: L. Cheat.
sp.p: 'Tis enough, we shall make the man hang himself.

sp.speaker: Y. Mag.
sp.p: Do you think I'll suffer you for ever to cross me with your damn'd insipid Songs? let me tell you, it is a grand impertinance.

sp.speaker: Prig.
sp.p: Gad, I do not know what you mean by your Gibberish but I suppose you call me impertinent, and therefore I'll be before-hand with you, you are a Son of a Whore.
sp.stage: [gives Y. Mag a box on the Ear.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.p: I will wait upon the Ladies.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Hold, hold.

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: Let'em alone, if you offer to part 'em, they'll hurt one another.

sp.speaker: Y. Mag.
sp.p: Ill not be Brutal, you shall answer for it▪ Sir, you are lately come out of France, and cannot deny a Man of Honour your assistance.

sp.speaker: Prig.
sp.p: Prithee Stanmore be my Second, Ill wit him with a Pox to him.

sp.speaker: Y. Mag.
sp.p: To morrow morning, done.

sp.speaker: Prig.
sp.p: Let my Second appoint the place.

sp.speaker: Y. Mag.
sp.p: With all my heart; Monsieur Carlos agree with him.

sp.speaker: Stan.
sp.p: Come, let's in, and put it off to the Ladies as if you were friends.

sp.speaker: Prig.
sp.p: Ay, with all my heart; what care I?

sp.speaker: Y. Mag.
sp.p: Morbleau, Brutal.

div.trailer: The End of the Second Act.

div.head: ACT III.
div.stage: Enter La. Cheatly, Carlos, Bellamore, Stanmore, Isabella, Theodosia, Gartrude, La. Busy, Young Maggot, Selfish, Prigg, Maggot, Lump.

sp.speaker: Lump.
sp.p: LAdy Sister, I am much offended to see you take this course of Vanity; would any wise Woman make use of Fidlers, Minstress and Singers? I am very much ashamed of it; it is folly, great folly, not becoming the blood of the Lumps.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: Lets withdraw, we shall have a Lesson from this formal Uncle.
sp.stage: [Ex. all but L. Cheat. Lump, Prigg, and Old Maggot.

sp.speaker: Gart.
sp.p: I can't abide him.

sp.speaker: Lump.
sp.p: What pleasure can there be to hear Fellows scrape upon Cats-guts? There's nothing in't.

sp.speaker: L. Cheat.
sp.p: 'Tis the way to get credit at our end of the Town, as singing Psalms, and praying loud in a fore-Room, is at yours.

sp.speaker: Lump.
sp.p: You talk not wisely; do not several godly men by those means, and by frequenting Meetings, get credit enough to break for a hundred thousand pound, and are made by it for ever.

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.p: He is one of the wisest men of the Nation, he is a mighty sober, solid Fellow, and a rare man at business, and loves business mightily.

sp.speaker: Lump.
sp.p: And for the Wits that come hither, I doubt not but these Gentlemen are of my opinion; I say, they are dangerous, scandalous, and good for nothing.

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.p: 'Tis true, Madam, they are a company of flashy, frothy Fellows; and have no solidity in them.

sp.speaker: L. Cheat.
sp.p: I find these Coxcombs mistake dulness for solidity.

sp.speaker: Prig.
sp.p: They talk of Wit, and this and that, and keep a Coyl and a Pother about Wit, there's nothing at all in't, what a Pox is't good for? I would not give a farthing for Wit; here's Young Maggot, and Selfish, why they don't know how to bett at a Horse-Race, or make a good Match at Tennis, and are cross-bitten at Bowls; hang Wit..

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.p: Wit is one of the Grievances of the Nation.

sp.speaker: Lump.
sp.p: It is, as this Gentleman has wisely observ'd, a Grievance, a fore Grievance, and I would have an Act of Parliament against it.

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.p: Let me take a Wit at Business, see how I'll handle him, I would not be a Wit for all the World.

sp.speaker: Prig.
sp.p: Nor I neither, I hate it, they are a company of fleering, jeering, ill natur'd Fellows to boot too.

sp.speaker: L. Cheat.
sp.p: Be comforted, Gentlemen, you are in no danger.

sp.speaker: Lump.
sp.p: I say they are in danger, and you too, of catching it; if you suffer them to come amongst ye; I have known solid men by keeping that base company, become Witty, and have ruin'd themselves; for my own part, I would as soon catch the Plague, as that Disease of Wit..

sp.speaker: L. Cheat.
sp.p: Oh Brother! you have a strong Antidote against it.

sp.speaker: Lump.
sp.p: Thanks be to Heaven, I have Wits! out upon 'em; they write Satyrs upon good men, and will laugh at wise men.

sp.speaker: L. Cheat.
sp.p: Why truly, Brother, sometimes wise men will provoke 'em very much.

sp.speaker: Lump.
sp.p: You are i'th wrong.

sp.speaker: Steward.
sp.p: Here is your Scrivener, Mr. Lump, and several others met, upon Money-business.

sp.speaker: Lump.
sp.p: I ordered mine to come to you; I have four thousand pound paid in this day, which you may use; I will leave my Scrivener to take your Assignments, either of Bonds, Judgments, or Mortgages, as it shall happen to be dispos'd by you.

sp.speaker: L. Cheat.
sp.p: But will the Scrivener be true, and publish it to be my Money?

sp.speaker: Lump.
