sp.p: I warrant you, he's a godly Man, and you may trust him, he has contributed more to your Fame than any one; I my self have brought in Ananias, and he will send Money to you, to put out for him. 'Tis near four, I must be gone; though hast does not become a wise man, yet at the present I have some upon me.

sp.speaker: L. Cheat.
sp.p: The hast of a Fool is the slowest thing in the World.

sp.speaker: Lump.
sp.p: It is my hour of Walking.

sp.speaker: L. Cheat.
sp.p: Will you not stay and take the Assignments?

sp.speaker: Lump.
sp.p: I will not break my Method for the World; I have these twenty years walk't through Turn-stile Alley to Holborn Fields at Four, all the good WOmen observe me, and set their Bread into the Oven by me, and by no other Clock; when I go by, I hear 'em call, Carry the Bread to the Oven, the old Gentleman is going by; I do love to be taken notice of for my Method. Farewel.

sp.speaker: L. Cheat.
sp.p: Let's into the Garden.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: By Heaven, I love thee more than light or liberty, joy of my heart.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: Such hearts as yours are seldom near their mouthes.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: A kiss of this fair hand will bring mine thither; 'tis there, but if it were your lips, where would it be?

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: Raptures in Love have no more meaning in 'em than Rants in Poetry, meer Fustian; 'tis the stum of Love that makes it fret and fume, and fly, and never good.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Can a young Lady in so warm an Age be insensible of Love?

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p:
A vertuous Woman is ever insensible of such a Love as is unfit for her; but you Sparks, like Wolves, after many battels, by often preying upon Carkasses, come at last to venture upon the living:
modest or not, 'tis all one to you, you are so well flesht.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Not so, Madam; I know my duty and your worth, and would time stand still, I could be content to gaze upon that face, and not tempt you; but our Love is frail, and we must take our pleasures while we may.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: I must consider while I may, and on the shore think on the ruines of a ship wrackt Fame.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: We shall never reach Love's Indies, if we fear tempests already.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: Think not to conquer me by dint of Simile, I'll never venture the pain and peril of such a bold Voyage.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: As tender Barks make it daily, and return home richly fraught, keep Coaches, and live splendidly the rest of their lives.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: Infamously rather.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: I know not that; but they have their days of Visiting, play at Ombre, make Treats as high and as often as the Persons of Quality, wear as good cloaths, and want no fashionable Folly that Woman's heart can wish for, and of all such my Isabella shall ride Admiral.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: Can you pretend to love, and tempt me from my Honour? Coaches and Cloaths! so Rogues will 〈◊〉 to live like Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: 'Tno dishonour, custom has made it otherwise.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: When a Man of Honour can turn Coward, you may prevail on me; the case is equal.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: On the contrary, Kindness in Women is like Courage in Men.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: Did not the general licence of the time excuse you, I ne'r would see you more.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: What will nothing down, but to have and to hold? I'll marry no body else, and when my inclination dies, leave you its wealthy Widow, you may marry after it.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: I'll bring no infamy, where I bring my person.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: This coldness inflames me more: consent to my desires, and none of all the Ladies shall outshine, no Equipage exceed yours.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: And I the while shall be but a part of your Equipage, to be kept; what is it but to wear your Livery, and take Board-wages?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: I love you well enough to marry you, but dare not put my self into your hands, knowing what a Jade I am at a long Journey.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: If you ever loved, you can never hate, and I can be content where I have had the best, to keep the 〈◊〉 and if you love me less, shall lay the fault on Nature, not on you.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p:
It goes more against a man's heart to fall in his Love, than his Expence, and they that do either, most commonly remove for it,
there is no enduring it in the same place. Think on my Love, my Fortune shall be yours.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: I scorn a Fortune, with the ruine of my Honour.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: It is but heading with another sort of People, leaving the melancholy hypocrites for the gay chearful sinners, the envious for the envyed.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: These tales may catch unheedful silly Creatures, whom Nature half debauches to your hands; but for my self I swear.

sp.speaker: La. Bus.
sp.p: Swear not, ungracious Child, I have heard all your Discourse; the Gentleman is a fine Gentleman, and his proposals are as reasonable as any Lady can wish for; every man cannot bring himself to marry, and yet may love better and longer than those that do.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Right, Madam: this is an unexpected assistance.

sp.speaker: La. Bus.
sp.p: There's Mr. Maggot kept Mrs. Wagtail, after the whole Town had done with her, and loves her very well still; nay, some have not grutch'd to spend ten thousand pounds upon a Mistress, though they have starv'd their Wives and Children.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: Have you fee'd this Lady to plead for you, or is it the baseness of her own Nature?

sp.speaker: La. Bus.
sp.p: Is my Charity thus rewarded? my Honour question'd I that am companion to the Ladies of the best quality, the jealousest Lord thinks his Lady safe in my company, my Honour is dearer to me than all the World, and but for endeavouring to have you well settled in the World, as I have my Daughters, do I deserve this?

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: She is as silly as she's naught; when you see me next, bring nobler thoughts and better purposes. And so farewel.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: What a Devil shall I do? She's vertuous, and fit enough for a Wife; Ounds, how that word makes me start? but all this may be a copy of her countenance, there may be Huffs in vertue as well as courage.

sp.speaker: La. Bus.
sp.p: I hope, Sir, you'll not conceive amiss for what she says.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: No, Madam: Pox on this Bawd, I love the treason, but I hate the traytor.

sp.speaker: Stan.
sp.p: Your humble Servant, Madam; has your Ladyship had the goodness to mind my Affair?

sp.speaker: L. Busy.
sp.p: I have, Sir; I see her coming, retire, and let me alone. Come pretty Mrs. Gatty.

sp.speaker: Gart.
sp.p: Your Servant, Madam.

sp.speaker: L. Busy.
sp.p: Thou art a pretty Creature, ah! 'twould do a man good to lye by such flesh and blood as thou art; all the matter is to chuse a good Bedfellow, and for that trust me; there is the prettiest man, and the finest Gentleman not far off.—

sp.speaker: Gart.
sp.p: Ay, so there is really; Mr. Selfish is the finest person, so civil, and well bred, and is very ingenious too, I vow 'twould do one good to have such a Bedfellow.

sp.speaker: L. Busy.
sp.p: You are out, 'tis Mr. Stanmore is the Man, and will make a good Settlement, go to, which the other cannot.

sp.speaker: Gart.
sp.p: He is a fine Gentleman indeed, but really I don't care for a Wit, I do not know what to say before 'em; but I can talk with Mr. Selfish all the day long, oh! he does tell such pretty Stories of himself! he is a very fair spoken man, and I'll swear he is the purest company for a Lady that ever was, and so handsom.

sp.speaker: L. Busy.
sp.p: Not comparable to Stanmore.

sp.speaker: Gart.
sp.p: Oh Gemini! that your Ladyship should say so.

sp.speaker: L. Busy.
sp.p: I have experience in the World, I know what I say, your Lady Mother has desired me to take care to put you into the World: youth is indiscreet and unwary, trust us, and 'twill be your own another day; I say, Mr. Stanmore will settle ten times more upon you than the other is worth.

sp.speaker: Gart.
sp.p: But really, Madam, I must confess I don't love a Wit, they say they are not good natur'd, and they don't admire one half so much as others do neither.

sp.speaker: L. Busy.
sp.p: Come, come, Madam, if a Wit will keep, he will serve as well as a Fool (let 'em say what they will) and you have a way to be too hard for the best of 'em for all their Wits.

sp.speaker: Gart.
sp.p: Oh Lord, here he is! I wonder you should say Mr. Stanmore is as handsom as he; well, he's a lovely Man.

sp.speaker: Self.
sp.p: Ladies, I kiss both your hands; methinks I see the freshness of the Spring in one, and the fruitfulness of the Autumn in the other.

sp.speaker: Gart.
sp.p: Oh rare, what a saying that is, and so like a Gentleman?

sp.speaker: Stan.
sp.p: Now 'tis time to speak for my self; she is very pretty, but why should I love a Fool, that loves a Fool▪ I see I am a devilish carnal Fellow, and mind nothing but the Body.

sp.speaker: L. Busy.
sp.p: I'll steal out to my Lady, and leave you, we have business of consequence.

sp.speaker: Stan.
sp.p: Madam, your humble Servant.

sp.speaker: Self.
sp.p: Mr. Stanmore, your Servant; were you not at the Audience this Afternoon?

sp.speaker: Stan.
sp.p: No, Sir.

sp.speaker: Self.
sp.p: Indeed I have committed a great fault, to wait upon these Ladies, when the Court was to appear in all the splendor it could be, with all the well-drest and well-bred men about it, and I was not there; I wish it be not taken ill.

sp.speaker: Stan.
sp.p: O Vanity, vanity!

sp.speaker: Self.
sp.p: I know I was miss't, and ask't for there, but I can mind nothing when Ladies are in the way, especially such pretty Creatures as Mrs. Gatty.

sp.speaker: Gart.
sp.p: You are pleas'd to say so.

sp.speaker: Stan.
sp.p: Well, my dear little one, I am resolv'd to be reveng'd upon this Beauty of yours, for making me so mad in Love with you.

sp.speaker: Gart.
sp.p: Why, what will you do with it?

sp.speaker: Stan.
sp.p: I'll have no mercy on't, I'll never spare it, faith, you shan't think to make me in Love with you for nothing.

sp.speaker: Self.
sp.p: I shall have a new Suit come home to morrow morning, in Mr. Carlos his fashion; but I assure you 'tis something better fancied, both for the Colour and the Garniture.

sp.speaker: Gart.
sp.p: Really, Sir, methinks Mr. Selfish is the prettiest modish person, and so gentile, is not he?

sp.speaker: Stan.
sp.p: S'heart, what an entertainment is this to me, that I should love such a thing? don't mistake him, he is an Ass, I assure you.

sp.speaker: Gart.
sp.p: Oh Lord, that you should say so now! he does every thing so like a Gentleman, as my Lady Busy says, and is so well-bred.

sp.speaker: Stan.
sp.p: Well-bred? hang him, he is a finical Clown, he has not breeding enough for a Valet de Chambre.

sp.speaker: Gart.
sp.p: What a strange man are you? well, you Wits never speak well of one another, I vow.

sp.speaker: Stan.
sp.p: Ounds, what a pretty Fool she is? but I am vigorous still, her folly cannot thrust me off, so much as her beauty pulls me to.

sp.speaker: Self.
sp.p: I am going to buy me a pretty convenient Coach, what Colour do you fancy, dear Mrs. Gatty? I think Purple will suit best with my Complexion.

sp.speaker: Gart.
sp.p: O yes, Purple will be very pretty.

sp.speaker: Self.
sp.p:
Nay, I'll say that for my self, my fancy always pleases the
Ladies. Pretty Miss, let me see that delicate Busk, I will write a Distick upon it, and present it to you.

sp.speaker: Gart.
sp.p: Pray do.

sp.speaker: Self.
sp.p: Let me kiss that happy Busk, that goes so near your lovely body, and that delicate, sweet, white, soft hand that gave it me.

sp.speaker: Gart.
sp.p: Well, he's a rare Man, and is so full of fine Courtship.

sp.speaker: Stan.
sp.p: Do you know that I will not suffer you to smile, and cringe, and play the Monkey here?

sp.speaker: Self.
sp.p: I cannot help it; if Ladies will love me, and be affected with my person, what is it to me?

sp.speaker: Stan.
sp.p: Get you gone, you Coxcomb, I'll endure it no longer.
sp.stage: [he fillips him, and pulls off his Peruque.

sp.speaker: Gart.
sp.p: Nay, what have you done to poor Mr. Selfish?

sp.speaker: Self.
sp.p: I wonder you should have no more breeding, one would have thought I might have taught you more in this time.

sp.speaker: Gart.
sp.p: Pray let me help you, I'll set it right again.

sp.speaker: Stan.
sp.p: Death and damnation! what's this?

sp.speaker: Self.
sp.p: The Devil take me, if I could not find in my heart to ruffle your Cravat, before the Lady, for this outrage of yours.

sp.speaker: Stan.
sp.p: Do you hear, Sir? be gone, and leave us, or by Heaven I will cut your Throat.

sp.speaker: Self.
sp.p: Well, I cannot be ill bred, though you can, and therefore I take my leave.

sp.speaker: Gart.
sp.p: Nay, look you now, udds fiddles, what have you done? you have made Mr. Selfish go away. I'll follow him, that I will.

sp.speaker: L. Cheat.
sp.p: Do you hear, Minx? be civiller, than I hear you are, to Mr. Stanmore, and know, I'll turn you out of my house, if you think on Selfish. Sir, your Servant.

sp.speaker: Gart.
sp.p: Oh lack! what does she say?

sp.speaker: Stan.
sp.p: Nay, I'll follow you.

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.p: Catch her, Man, she'll be a vast Fortune, my Lady wallows in money, she knows not what to do with it. But, good Madam, let me humbly petition you to consider my passion, and have some regard to my Estate, which is a plentiful one. And then, Madam, for business, you see a proof; did you ever see a man tell money better than I do; I do all the Ladies business hereabouts, and great Persons, 〈◊〉.

sp.speaker: L. Cheat.
sp.p: I must first consider of reducing my Estate into some order, before I think of disposing my Person.

sp.speaker: Magg.
sp.p: If any Man sollicits your business like me— try me, Madam, I do every thing for the Ladies.

sp.speaker: Stew.
sp.p: Madam, I have private business for your Ladyship's Ear.

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.p: Your Servant, Madam, I will retire, be pleased to consider me.

sp.speaker: Stew.
sp.p: My business concerns your Ladyship and my self so nearly, that you must pardon me, if I urge it home.

sp.speaker: L. Cheat.
sp.p: What means he?

sp.speaker: Stew.
sp.p: That I have serv'd you faithfully, your self can witness.

sp.speaker: L. Cheat.
sp.p: I can, and I'll reward you largely.

sp.speaker: Stew.
sp.p: 'Tis that I ask. Think, Madam, I have in your Service lost my honesty, lay'd by my conscience, and while I contribute to your fraud or others, I must not be deceiv'd my self.

sp.speaker: L. Cheat.
sp.p: What will he drive at? I am sorry you ask for what I intended to give you; I did resolve to give you a thousand pound.

sp.speaker: Stew.
sp.p: Do not I know that all the Bonds you have given to people, and the Assignments, and Declarations of Trust to your Brother, are written with the ink I bought of a great Artist, and that within a moneth it will wear out, and nothing will remain but blanks?

sp.speaker: L. Cheat.
sp.p: What then? my Husband was cheated of his Estate by my Brother, and other Rascals, and 'tis fit I should take Letters of Reprisal.

sp.speaker: Stew.
sp.p: No doubt. Your Bounds you have taken from others are written with ink I had of the same man, which (rubb'd over with a spirit) makes impressions into many sheets, so that you have many Bonds for one, the sums are easily altered.

sp.speaker: L. Cheat.
sp.p: What would this Rascal have?

sp.speaker: Stew.
sp.p: A thousand pound! I scorn it, I aim at higher things, I am a Gentleman in birth, your Equal.

sp.speaker: L. Cheat.
sp.p: Heaven and Earth! what have I brought my self to? When my Estate is out of dispute, I will increase your reward.

sp.speaker: Stew.
sp.p: No, Madam; I have long honour'd and lov'd your Ladyship, and nothing less than your Person can ever satisfie me.

sp.speaker: L. Cheat.
sp.p: How, Sir!

sp.speaker: Stew.
sp.p: Hold, Madam; if you use me roughly, I in a moment will blast all your Fortunes, and you shall fly from hence as naked as you came; but if you'll marry me, Ill be as humble a Servant as I have been before.

sp.speaker: L. Cheat.
sp.p: Insolent Villain.
Sure thou art not in earnest.

sp.speaker: Stew.
sp.p: By Heaven, I am, and I will perish, or attain my ends.

sp.speaker: L. Cheat.
sp.p: He may undo me; Oh that I should lay my Plots so shalllow! I must have a trick for the Rogue.
Give me time to consider of it.

sp.speaker: Stew.
sp.p: I can give none, nor will.

sp.speaker: L. Cheat.
sp.p: Marriage would stop my business, and I shall get no more money of my Brother, or others.

sp.speaker: Stew.
sp.p: We'll keep it private.

sp.speaker: L. Cheat.
sp.p: (Though modesty would not let me propose it to you, and I would rather have died than done it) I must confess the thing I wish'd for upon Earth.

sp.speaker: Stew.
sp.p: Then I am happy, and will serve you 'till my death.

sp.speaker: L. Cheat.
sp.p: Forgive this frailty, and use me well, shame and blushes will confound me.

sp.speaker: Stew.
sp.p: Dear Madam! there's no shame in Love and Marriage. I see she loves me.

sp.speaker: L. Cheat.
sp.p: There yet remains one difficulty; You are my main Witness, and (when we are married) you can be none; therefore if you will go to a Master in Chancery, and swear to all my Deeds, and make Affidavit to my false Estate, the next hour shall make you Master of me, and mine.

sp.speaker: Stew.
sp.p: Hah! I may be catch'd, and after I have sworn to that, I have no hank upon her.
Before, Madam, I never will; but after, for my own sake, I must. I'll get a Parson (whom I can trust) and none shall know of the Marriage but himself.

sp.speaker: L. Cheat.
sp.p: This will not do, I must have another-trick for the Rascal. [aside. You have convinc'd me; but I am engaged to a Parson already, whom I promised that Office to; I'll send for him present'y.

sp.speaker: Stew.
sp.p: I am transported with my happiness.

sp.speaker: L. Cheat.
sp.p: Withdraw, Sir, I'll come to you instantly.
Hah! this Fellow shall be my Engine, and I must lose no time.

sp.speaker: L. Cheat.
sp.p: I am glad you are come; I have a business to communicate to you, that concerns you nearly, in which you must be secret.

sp.speaker: Prig.
sp.p: Does it concern my Honour? Madam, I'll cut their throats.

sp.speaker: L. Cheat.
sp.p: No, Sir, it concerns your Love.

sp.speaker: Prig.
sp.p: Then I'll cut their throats too.

sp.speaker: L. Cheat.
sp.p:
No, it is not come to that; but just as I was resolv'd (having
considered your passion, to bestow my self upon you.)—

sp.speaker: Prig.
sp.p: Oh dear Madam! let me kiss your fair hand.

sp.speaker: L. Cheat.
sp.p: Would you believe it? this villainous Steward having Writings in his hands for the greatest part of my Estate, is arriv'd to that insolence, he threatens to burn 'em, unless I will instantly marry him.

sp.speaker: Prig.
sp.p: Oh dog! Rogue! your Servant, Madam, I'll cut his throat immediately.

sp.speaker: L. Cheat.
sp.p: Hold, Sir, he's an odd humorous Fellow, and will not have his throat cut.

sp.speaker: Prig.
sp.p: Will he not? why then I won't.

sp.speaker: L. Cheat.
sp.p: I have design'd a better way; to put a false Marriage upon him, and you shall be my Chaplain, you can get the habit of a Parson.

sp.speaker: Prig.
sp.p: Ay, ay, this is very pretty; I your Chaplain? ha, ha! if my face would but look solid enough for a Divine.

sp.speaker: L. Cheat.
sp.p: I warrant you, 'tis a very judicious face, and will be very Parsonical.

sp.speaker: Prig.
sp.p: Not so, a Gamster's at your service.

sp.speaker: L. Cheat.
sp.p: And you can read the Common-Prayer, that's material; for some Gentlemen can scarce read now adays.

sp.speaker: Prig.
sp.p: I warrant you, Madam: this will be the prettiest trick.

sp.speaker: L. Cheat.
sp.p: When you have married him and me, about an hour hence (no body else being by) I'll take care to pack him far enough afterwards, and thus reserve my self for you. Get a Habit quickly, and lay it in the Closet, here's the Key, there you shall shift; I must be gone.

sp.speaker: Prig.
sp.p: Oh happy Man! I shall never need to sneak after a Lord, to sing Catches, break Jests, to eat and rook with him; well, I'll go no more to Twelve, that's certain; I'll get me a pack of Fox-Dogs, hunt every day, and play at the Groom-Porter's at night.

div.stage: Enter Theodosia and I sabella in the Garden.

sp.speaker: Theod.
sp.p: Dear Isabella, how I love these solitary Walks, free from the noise and importunity of Men.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: So much the contrary, that should you hear the ratling of a Coach, you'd be ready to leap over the Wall.

sp.speaker: Theod.
sp.p: If it were Bellamour's.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: Why Bellamour's? no, though you knew it to be a tired Hackney, with six dusty Passengers in't; thou art the giddiest Creature.

sp.speaker: Theod.
sp.p: I do not love to be solid as you are, and fix upon one Man; 'tis better to like all, and love none.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: Thou hypocrite; do not I know that none but Carlos can please you, he has caught you fast?

sp.speaker: Theod.
sp.p: No, never think so: Do but hear the Men talk of another, and 'tis antidote enough against 'em, they are as malicious as we Women, and would quarrel as often, if it were not for fear of fighting.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: Of all men I wonder Stanmore scapes it, he speaks well of no man.

sp.speaker: Theod.
sp.p: 'Tis fit to speak ill of Fops, who were lost to the World, if men of Wit might not show 'em.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: For ought I see, laughing at them does them no hurt; for they rise and get Fortunes for all that; Fools are lawful prize; but Stanmore speaks ill of witty men.

sp.speaker: Theod.
sp.p: When the witty men fall upon one another, they make sport for the fools, and so laughing goes round, no matter how.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: Stanmore says, Carlos has an ill breath, and takes Physick of a French Surgeon; and that Bellamore keeps a Player, and will run out his Estate.

sp.speaker: Theod.
sp.p: And yet you see how dear they are one to another when they meet, 'tis tis the fashion.

sp.speaker: Gart.
sp.p: Oh Sister, come hither! here are four men measuring of swords, I believe they are going to fight in the next field.
sp.stage: [Carlos, Prigg, Stanmore, and Young Maggot in the field.

sp.speaker: Yo. Mag.
sp.p: How shall I kill this Prigg? he wants two of his vital parts, a Brain and a Heart.

sp.speaker: Prig.
sp.p: I'll spoil your writing; have at your Madrigal arm, you Wit you.
sp.stage: [Prigg disarms Yo.▪ Mag. and comes up to Carlos.

sp.speaker: Stan.
sp.p: Carlos, you see our advantage.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: And scorn it; have at you first.
Now, Sir, for you.

sp.speaker: Stan.
sp.p: We are friends, I love thee, prithee let it alone.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Not so great friends, I over-heard you speaking ill of me to my Mistress.

sp.speaker: Stan.
sp.p: Prithee Carlos, that's nothing, we all speak ill of one another, and it goes for nothing.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: I am not of your opinion, have at you.

sp.speaker: Stan.
sp.p: At you? well, you have it, and I am glad I had to do with a brave man.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: You are men of Honour, and may be trusted with your swords; let's in amongst the Ladies, as if nothing had pass'd between us.

sp.speaker: Prig.
sp.p: You may do what you will; but the valiant Prig desires his Widow may hear of his prowess at least.

sp.speaker: Yo. Mag.
sp.p: That I should be worsted by an Ass.

sp.speaker: Gert.
sp.p: I am afraid Carlos has hurt honest Mr. Stanmore; but Carlos is a fine Gentleman, and fights so like a Gentleman, he said the prettiest things to me in an Arbor, Mr. Selfish could not have courted me at a higher rate, I vow I begin to like him strangely, I like a Wit better than I did.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: Thou'lt like any Body.

sp.speaker: Theod.
sp.p: Pray Heaven Carlos be not hurt.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: You seem disordered.

sp.speaker: Theod.
sp.p: No, no, what makest thou think so?

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: I am confident Carlos is not hurt.

sp.speaker: Theod.
sp.p: I think not of him.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: I cannot blame you; I believe he has honesty to his wit, and honour to his courage, I never saw a finer Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Gert.
sp.p: He has almost as taking a way with him as Mr. Selfish.

sp.speaker: Theod.
sp.p: I don't like his face, 'tis too serious; his meen is stiff, and he dances ill.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: You are too nice; his looks and meen are manly, and he dances like a person of quality; you are for a Page's face, and a dancing Master's legs, and I hate both.

sp.speaker: Theod.
sp.p: Nay, never let's fall out about him.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: If we should, he's here to part us.

div.stage: Enter Carlos, Prigg, and Young Maggot.

sp.speaker: Theod.
sp.p: He goes on faster with his task than I'd have him.

sp.speaker: Yo. Mag.
sp.p: There is no living two hours out of the Beau mond; I am out of the Lady's company like a Fish out of the water, is not that well said, Prigg?

sp.speaker: Prig.
sp.p: Not at all, the Devil take me.

sp.speaker: Theod.
sp.p: Not so mute as a Fish, I hope.

sp.speaker: Yo. Mag.
sp.p: No; we witty men are always talking, now and then two or three of us at a time, invention does so flow; but I had rather say one fine thing to a Lady, than twenty to the best Wits in Town.

sp.speaker: Prig.
sp.p: Say fine things? what a Pox don't we all speak alike? don't we all speak English?

sp.speaker: Theod.
sp.p: Had you never a Mistress that was a Fool?

sp.speaker: Yo. Mag.
sp.p: None are so gross but they guess when a man says a witty thing; when I say it, I am sure.

sp.speaker: Prig.
sp.p: Pox on saying, I love doing a witty thing; to win a man's money is to out-wit him, I think, and I'll undertake to win yours at ten several Games.

sp.speaker: Yo. Mag.
sp.p: What, cheat me?

sp.speaker: Prig.
sp.p: No, upon the square, by meer judgment. A Wit is like a running Horse, godd for no earthly thing beside; when did you ever know any of▪ em well with a great Man, or so much as taken down to a Lord's house a Buck-hunting? they can drink some of 'em; but then they talk of Philosophy, History, Poetry, as if they came into company to study; this is stuff the Devil would not hear.

sp.speaker: Theod.
sp.p: What would you have 'em talk of?

sp.speaker: Prig.
sp.p: Why Dogs, Hawks and Horses, Crimp, Trick track, and Primero; make me a match at Bowls or Tennis over a Bottle; ●…ome, even or odd for two Pieces, I hate to be idle.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: What an intolerable Fool is this?

sp.speaker: Prig.
sp.p: There are three matches to be run at New-market, I'll bett money on every one of 'em: I'll▪ ll hold you six to four of the Gelding against the Mare; gold to silver on the bay Stone-horse against the Flea-bitten; and an even fifty pound, or what you will.—

sp.speaker: Yo. Mag.
sp.p: You need not run your self out of breath, I will never bett while I live.

sp.speaker: Prig.
sp.p: Ladies, what think you of five merry Guineys? will either of you bett?

sp.speaker: Theod.
sp.p: I do not like Carlos his talking so long with that Fool; she is young and handsom, she has beauty enough to invite, and folly enough to grant.

sp.speaker: Prig.
sp.p: I hold five pound I make a Tennis-ball lye upon that Stand once in thrice.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: This Fellow has no Genius but to play, nor no argument but a wager.

sp.speaker: Yo. Mag.
sp.p: One that wants Wit, deserves not to bear the figure of a Man.

sp.speaker: Theod.
sp.p: Such Fellows are but cyphers to you men of Wit, they make you of greater value.

sp.speaker: Yo. Mag.
sp.p: I'll swear that's well said, I don't think I could have said better my self.

sp.speaker: Prig.
sp.p: What will you give me for this Ring at the day of Marriage?

sp.speaker: Carlos.
sp.p: You are so pretty, and so obliging, there's no resisting both. But will you come and see my Lodgings? I have the finest French things.

sp.speaker: Gert.
sp.p: Really, Sir, you are so courteous and well-behaved, I cannot deny you coming; you put me so in mind of Mr. Selfish, you have his way with you to a hair: do you write too? he is a very pretty Poet.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Were I not sharp set, this would turn my stomach: Selfish steals all he writes out of French Poetry; he has neither Wit nor Money but what he borrows, forget him, and I'll be your Servant.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: — Well, Theodosia, if I be false, 'tis your command has pusht me into temptation.

sp.speaker: Prig.
sp.p: Come, here's ten Guineys, I'll lay 'em upon my Toe, and in six times kick▪ em all into my mouth.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: And what if you do?

sp.speaker: Prig.
sp.p: Talk of Wit; Ill play at Prick-penny for twenty pound, with any one here.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: I am for you at Tennis.

sp.speaker: Prig.
sp.p: I'll give you a bisk at Longs for ten pound.

sp.speaker: Theod.
sp.p: Bowling methinks is better.

sp.speaker: Prig.
sp.p: I'll give him one in seven for five shillings.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: We had better reserve our strength; I'll hunt to morrow.

sp.speaker: Prig.
sp.p: With all my heart; hollo, hey Ringwood, Rockwood, Jowler, hey. Well, I'll go and play in the mean time: Pox, this is the basest company, there's no money stirring.

sp.speaker: Theod.
sp.p: What could you do with that Fool all this while?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: In obedience to your command, I suffered her impertinence: You are a very Tyrant; your Beauty obliges me to love none but you, and yet you'll have me make Love to all; flesh and blood is not able to bear it.

sp.speaker: Theod.
sp.p: Not so: I would have you gain their esteem, and be cryed up among 'em; using us scurvily, often does that; Women love the careless, insolent, and loud.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Faith, Madam, I am a moral man, I do as I would be done by.

sp.speaker: Theod.
sp.p: I would not be in Love with you for a million, 'twould tempt you horribly.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: It would tempt me to vanity, but never to ingratitude.

sp.speaker: Theod.
sp.p: Vanity and ingratitude are as inseparable as old age and ugliness; they that think too well of themselves, ever think too ill of others; and I will give you no temptation of any kind.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: You are nothing but temptation; your face, your shape, your voice, nay, your very coldness is a tempter, and therefore have a care on't.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: You have met with the greatest Tyrant of our Sex.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: The greatest Conqueror: But she has too much goodness for a Tyrant; however, I'll tire her cruelty with my patience, and I'll hold her the greatest wager in the World that I get her heart at last.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: A Wedding night:

sp.speaker: Theod.
sp.p: Who shall be Judg?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Your Friend here.

sp.speaker: Theod.
sp.p: I can't have a better; done.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Done, Madam; I am sure good service and perseverance will gain a reasonable Woman, where there is not a down-right antipa▪ thy, and I am resolved never to give you over.

sp.speaker: Theod.
sp.p: Love in this Age is as well counterfeited as Complexion; what with the Men's lying and swearing, and the Women's waters and washes, we know not what to make of one another.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Try me with Commands.

sp.speaker: Theod.
sp.p: I must have you Poetical, that's a great sign of Love in a Man of Wit; I must have Songs and Sonnets plenty.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Very well.

sp.speaker: Theod.
sp.p: I must never have you see a Play but when I am there.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: That is, I must see none at all; for when you are there, I can see nothing but your self.

sp.speaker: Theod.
sp.p: Then upon no pretence whatsoever must you go behind the Scenes.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: That's grown the sign of a Fop, and for my own sake I'll avoid it.

sp.speaker: Theod.
sp.p: But the Women have Beauty and Wit enough to hearken▪ to a Keeper.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Some of 'em are so far from having Wit of their own, that they spoyl that little the Poets put into 'em, by base utterance; and for Beauty they lay it on so, that 'tis much alike from fifteen to five▪ and forty.

sp.speaker: Theod.
sp.p: Item, You must not talk with Vizors in the Pit, though they look never so like Women of quality, and are never so coming.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Be it so: I never knew any good come of that way of fooling yet; for if they were afraid of me, I was ever more afraid of them. But how shall I arrive at the general Fame and Reputation you spoke of, with these restraints? The Men in vogue forbear none of all these things; they dive like Ducks at one end of the Pit, and rise at the other, then whisk into the Whore-Boxes, then into the Scenes, and always hurry up and down, the Devils in an Opera are not so busie.

sp.speaker: Theod.
sp.p: You must take other Courses.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: I have bespoken a Play for you, and all the good company of this House; when the other is done, I hope, Madam, you will honour it with your presence.

sp.speaker: Theod.
sp.p: I'll do as the rest do.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: This is a new piece of Gallantry, Theodosia.

sp.speaker: Theod.
sp.p: The invitation's general.

sp.speaker: Gar.
sp.p: How mad would they be, if they knew this were meant to me?

div.stage: Enter Maggot, unseen by the rest.

sp.speaker: Yo. Mag.
sp.p: Now pretty Mrs. Gartrude, and the rest of the good company, I have the Poem about me, which I told you I writ upon Beauty; 'tis elaborate, I kept my Chamber about it as long as a Spark does, of a Clap, or a Lady of a Child; I purged, and bled, and enter'd into a Diet about it, and that made me have so clear a Complexion, and write so well, and brought down my Belly too.

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.p: How now, Wit! let me see that damn'd Poem you lay in of so long, when you should have studied the Law.

sp.speaker: Yo. Mag.
sp.p: Oh Heaven! I am undone.

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.p: I shall spoyl that Moneth's Work.

sp.speaker: Yo. Mag.
sp.p: Ladies, pray intercede for me, and save my Poem.

sp.speaker: Theod.
sp.p: Hold, Sir, reprieve it.

sp.speaker: Yo. Mag.
sp.p: 'Tis not mine, 'tis a Friend's of mine.

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.p: Ah graceless Fool! the worst Friend thou hast, thy self thou meanest.

sp.speaker: Yo. Mag.
sp.p: Save this, and I will never be witty again.

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.p: No, Sir, there, there, so, 'tis done: By Heaven, touch a piece on't, and I'll dis-inherit you.
sp.stage: [Yo. Mag. goes to gather up the pieces.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Let me intercede for him, he'll mend, and be less witty every day.

sp.speaker: Yo. Mag.
sp.p: Forgive me once, and I'll mend, and be as dull as an old fat Alderman, that sleeps over Justice at the Old-Baily.

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.p: At your Simile's again, Oh you incorrigible Wit! let me see what Poetry you have about you.

sp.speaker: Yo. Mag.
sp.p: Ladies, for Heaven's sake, plead for me, or I am utterly ruin'd: Sir, will you disgrace me before my Mistress Gartrode?

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.p: Hang you, Coxcomb; she hates Wit, because she's a fool, as I do, because Iam wise. Stand still.

sp.speaker: Yo. Mag.
sp.p: Mercy upon me! what will become of me?

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: Good Mr. Maggot, be more merciful.

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.p: What's here? A Poem call'd, A Posie for the Ladies Delight. A second, The Flower of Love's Constancy. An Answer to it. Disticks to write upon Lady's Busks. Epigram written in a Lady's Bible in Covent-Garden- Church. Oh wicked Wit! Posies for Wedding-Rings, Oh idle Rake-hell! I shall have you come to write to Tobacco Boxes and Sword-Blades, and Knives, and to all the Iron-work at Sheffeild; all these go to it.

sp.speaker: Yo. Mag.
sp.p: Hold, good Sir, hold; upon my knees I beg you'ld hold: here cut off this Joynt, this, this, any Joynt about me, so you'll spare my Poetry.

sp.speaker: Theod.
sp.p: Have pity on the poor Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Gar.
sp.p: Oh pray give me those upon the Busks.

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.p: Not one shall live to make him in favour: Must you needs be a Wit, to the dishonour of your Family, and the distrubance of your good old Father's ashes? I never knew one of our Family before. I'll alter my Will instantly.

sp.speaker: Yo. Mag.
sp.p: Nay, now you may hang me and you will, now you have torn my Poetry, I have never a Copy of any of 'em; I will go hide my self in a hole and never shew my head again.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Come, Ladies, shall we prepare for the Play after this Farce?

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: With all our hearts.

div.trailer: The End of the Third Act.

div.head: ACT IV.
div.stage: Enter Carlos, Theodosia, Prigg, La. Cheatly Maggot, La Busy, Bellamore, Isabella, Stanmore, Gartrude, Young Maggot, and Selfish, and others coming into the Play-house, seating themselves. The Scene, The Play-house.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: BY being masqued, I shall observe Bellamore's Actions.

sp.speaker: Gart.
sp.p: Now no Body will know me; they'll take me for you in this Petticoat.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: If you hold your Tongue, Sister; but that makes a great difference betwixt us.

sp.speaker: Gart.
sp.p: Ay; but I'll whisper, and they shall not know my voice.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: But they'll soon discover your sence.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: My dear Mistress, since you accept my service, I am resolv'd to ply you so, that I must win at last.

sp.speaker: Theod.
sp.p: You are very resolute, and shall find me so; you think to go on like the French King; we shall have you do as he does by a Town in Flanders, set a day when you will take it.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: I hope to corrupt you within with Love, and make my conquest the easier.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: I wonder Isabella is not here, Stanmore; I am so damnably in Love, I am afraid thou'lt never own me; I am a very Recreant.

sp.speaker: Stan.
sp.p: My Mistress is not here neither; her folly has a little cool'd my Love; but I have a most abominable lust to her, the wiser passion of the two, and no despair: Though that Rogue Selfish has her Mind, I do not doubt but to get her Body, which is worth two of it for my use.

sp.speaker: Yo. Mag.
sp.p: I wonder pretty Mrs. Gartrude is not here.

sp.speaker: Self.
sp.p: I am amaz'd at it; for she knew I was to come.

div.stage: A great knocking at the Door. Enter Door-keeper.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: How now! What means that knocking?

sp.speaker: Door-keep.
sp.p: Sir, Ladies and several Gentlemen knock to get in.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Let the Ladies in for nothing, but make the Men pay.

sp.speaker: Prig.
sp.p: Had you ever such a Chaplain? I was so disguis'd, he could not suspect me; methinks I dispatch'd the business as well, as if I had been used to be married my self.

sp.speaker: L. Cheat.
sp.p: 'Twas very well, I have since gotten my Deeds from him; and because he was a main Witness to many of my Bonds, and Mortgages, I have made him swear to 'em all before a Master in Chancery, upon pretence that when it should be known he was my Husband, his testimony would not be good.

sp.speaker: Prig.
sp.p: Ha! ha! ha! This was the prettiest invention, and will make well for us. But where is the Fool?

sp.speaker: L. Cheat.
sp.p: There is a Kinsman of mine going for the Indies, I sent him to him with an hundred pound for a Venture, and have taken care he shall not come back again; for he'll clap him under Hatches, carry him away, and sell him for a Rogue as he is; he sayls this Tide.

div.stage: Several more come in, Women mark'd, and Men of several sorts. Several young Coxcombs fool with the Orange-Women.

sp.speaker: Orange-Wo.
sp.p: Oranges; Will you have any Oranges?

sp.speaker: 1 Bull.
sp.p: What Play do they play? some confounded Play or other.

sp.speaker: Prig.
sp.p: A Pox on't, Madam! what should we do at this damn'd Play-house? Let's send for some Cards, and play at Lang-trilloo in the Box: Pox on'em! I ne'r saw a Play had any thing in't; some of 'em have Wit now and then, but what care I for Wit..

sp.speaker: Self.
sp.p: Does my Cravat sit well? I take all the care I can it should; I love to appear well. What Ladies are here in the Boxes? really I never come to a Play, but upon account of seeing the Ladies.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Door-keeper, Are they ready to begin?

sp.speaker: Door-keep.
sp.p: Yes, immediately.

sp.speaker: Self.
sp.p: Now you shall see the Ladies make up to me; where e're I am, they flock about me: I think I am one of the happiest Men on Earth; I thank Heaven every day for making me just as I am, Bellamore.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: That's Isabella, I am sure, I know the Petticoat; what a Devil makes her talk to that Rogue?

sp.speaker: Yo. Mag.
sp.p: You'll find it an admirable Plot; there's great force and fire in the writing; so full of business, and trick, and very fashionable; it pass'd through my hands; some of us helpt him in it.

sp.speaker: 1 Bull.
sp.p: Dam'me! When will these Fellows begin? Plague on't! here's a staying.

sp.speaker: 2 Man.
sp.p: Whose Play is this?

sp.speaker: 3 Man.
sp.p: One Prickett's, Poet Prickett.

sp.speaker: 1 Man.
sp.p: Oh hang him! Pox on him! he cannot write; prithee let's to White-hall.

sp.speaker: Y. Mag.
sp.p: Not write, Sir? I am one of his Patrons; I know the Wits don't like him; but he shall write with any of 'em all for an hundred pound.

sp.speaker: Prig.
sp.p: Ay that he shall. They say, he puts no Wit in his Plays, but 'tis all one for that, they do the business; he is my Poet too; I hate Wit..

div.stage: Enter several Ladies, and several Men.

sp.speaker: Door-keep.
sp.p: Pray, Sir, pay me, my Masters will make me pay it.

sp.speaker: 3 Man.
sp.p: Impudent-Rascal! Do you ask me for Money? Take that, Sirrah.

sp.speaker: 2 Door-keep.
sp.p: Will you pay me, Sir?

sp.speaker: 4 Man.
sp.p: No: I don't intend to stay.

sp.speaker: 2 Door-keep.
sp.p: So you say every day, and see two or three Acts for nothing.

sp.speaker: 4 Man.
sp.p: I'll break your Head, you Rascal.

sp.speaker: 1 Door-keep.
sp.p: Pray, Sir, pay me.

sp.speaker: 3 Man
sp.p: Set it down, I have no Silver about me, or bid my Man pay you.

sp.speaker: Theod.
sp.p: What, do Gentlemen run on tick for Plays?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: As familiarly as with their Taylors?

sp.speaker: 3 Door keep.
sp.p: Pox on you, Sirrah! go, and bid 'em begin quickly.
sp.stage: They play the Curtain-time, then take their places.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Now they ll begin.
sp.stage: [Selfish and Young Maggot go to sit down.

sp.speaker: Y. Mag.
sp.p: Don't come to us; let you Wits sit together.

sp.speaker: Prig.
sp.p: These Fellows will be witty, and trouble us; go to your Brother Wits, and make a noise among your selves, Brother Wits.

sp.speaker: Self.
sp.p: I am always hated by the Fools; but I think it rather out of envy than malice.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Faith! you shan't sit by us.

sp.speaker: Stan.
sp.p: Gentlemen, Do not mistake your selves, for you are no Wits, though y'are Poets, and we will not own you of our Party.

sp.speaker: Yo. Mag.
sp.p: This is meer envy against us Writers, Selfish.

sp.speaker: Self.
sp.p: It is so: I for my part will throw my self at a Lady's feet, play with her Fan, and fan her gently with it.

sp.speaker: Lover.
sp.p: Dear Madam, Let us not omit any occasion; but take every opportunity by the hand, to improve those Amours, which have rendred us so happy, to be elevated above the reach of Envy.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Sir, I should not entertain a thought, that might in any wise be prejudicial to our Amours, or the improvement thereof, if I were not so extremely obnoxious to the great infelicity of being subject to a Husband, whose Jealousie has so much the Ascendant over him, that it renders him so vigilant, not seldom to interrupt our happiest hours.

sp.speaker: Lover.
sp.p: That turbulent temper does too often disorder the fair quiet of his own mind, as well as discompose ours; and Jealousie proves as often an obstruction to his own tranquillity, as it does an impediment to our fruition.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p:
It is a priviledge too absolutely imperious (which by a seeming
Conjugal right) our Husbands claim over us, to make so subtil a scrutiny into all our enterprizes, since they, with too great a regretentertain the least motion of ours, whereby we would insinuate into their Affairs.

sp.speaker: Lover.
sp.p: But since Fortune (by so many frequent Signalizations) has demonstrated how much she is a friend to us, in assisting us with so many Subterfuges, when most we have needed them, it will be a hainous tergiversation from her, to abandon that trust we formerly have reposed in her, and she may justly take a Picque at our infidelity, and, in that Caprice, may contrive a revenge sutable to our delinquency.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Rather Fortune may be apt to believe us too audacious, in tempting her with so much importunity, that it must needs be more vexatious than agreeable; and while we make such vigorous addresses to another Deity, for ought we know, Love may wax jealous of our Applications to it: For though he's blind, he can descry, and will greatly resent our Dereliction; and, when he is incensed, his Nature is highly vindicative.

sp.speaker: Lover.
sp.p: When Fortune takes such pains to assist us in our Amours, Love will certainly be very sensible of our Omission; and when he is once provok'd, he seldom buries Injuries in the grave of Oblivion.

sp.speaker: Theod.
sp.p: This is very lewd Stuff: Is this the new way of Writing?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: A Man would think these Lovers in Plays did not care a farthing for one another, when they find nothing to do but to be florid, and talk impertinently when they are alone.

sp.speaker: Yo. Mag.
sp.p: This is a very strong, sinewy, and correct Style, and yet neat, and florid.

sp.speaker: Self.
sp.p: I have taught 'em all this way of Writing; I always strive to write like a Gentleman, so easie, and well bred.

sp.speaker: Prig.
sp.p: These are very good Lines, faith.

sp.speaker: Y. Mag.
sp.p: Nay, 'tis admirably worded, that's the truth on't:

sp.speaker: 1 Man.
sp.p: Dam'me! I don't like it.

sp.speaker: 2 Man.
sp.p: Pox on the Coxcomb that writ it! there's nothing in't.

sp.speaker: 1 Man.
sp.p: God I love Drums, and Trumpets, and much ranting, roaring, huffing, and fretting, and good store of noise in a Play.

sp.speaker: Lover.
sp.p: I have sufficiently confuted all your Argumentation; and nothing then remains, but that I should humbly petition to hold the Honour of your fair Embraces.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: The Motion is so civil, and savours so much of a sincere Affection, that I can no longer resist it.

sp.speaker: Lover.
sp.p: Let us retire.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Come.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: So: now they are come to the Matter in hand: But here comes the Husband.
sp.stage: The Husband knocks at the Door, and turns his back. The Lover kicks him several times, and retires:

sp.speaker: Yo. Mag.
sp.p: Now it begins to warm; 'tis an admirable Plot.

sp.speaker: Self.
sp.p: Bellamore, See how kind the Ladies are to me: Pretty Rogue! Let me repose my Head in thy soft Bosom.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: 'S death! What's this? She will not speak to me, yet suffers that familiarity with that Rascal, as if it were on purpose to provoke me.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Why does not the Fool look where the Blows come?

sp.speaker: Theod.
sp.p: Oh! that would spoyl the Plot.

sp.speaker: Husband.
sp.p: This must be the Devil that strikes me: Some whoring Rogue or other is gotten with my Wife, and the Devil pimps for him; but I have a Key to a Back-door, and will surprize him.

sp.speaker: Stan.
sp.p: I cannot find my Mistress; but I'll divert my self with a Vizard in the mean time.

sp.speaker: 1 Man.
sp.p: What, not a word? all over in disguise: Silence for your Folly, and a Vizard for your ill Face.

sp.speaker: 2 Man to a Vizard.
sp.p: Gad! some Whore, I warrant you, or Chamber-maid, in her Lady's old Cloaths.
sp.stage: [He sits down, and lolls in the Orange-wench's Lap.

sp.speaker: 3 Man.
sp.p: She must be a Woman of quality; she has right Point.

sp.speaker: 4 Man.
sp.p: Faith! she earns all the Cloaths on her Back by lying on't; some Punk lately turn'd out of Keeping, her Livery not quite worn out.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: I deserve this by coming in a Masque; and if I should now discover my self, 'twould make a Quarrel.

sp.speaker: Prig.
sp.p: You shall see what tricks I'll play; faith! I love to be merry.
sp.stage: [Raps people on the Backs, and twirls their Hats, and then looks demurely, as if he did not do it.

sp.speaker: 2 Lover.
sp.p: Have I catcht them? I was jealous of this before; but now I will make further discovery.

sp.speaker: 1 Lover.
sp.p: In verity it savours of Incivility, to interrupt our Joys in the middle of our Felicity; but since the barbarous Intruder is defeated, let us embrace the present occasion, which seems to court us.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: If any thing which I can do can felicitate you, you may command my Person.

sp.speaker: 2 Lover.
sp.p: Oh damn'd Jade!

div.stage: The Husband falls over a Form, and breaks his Shins, and puts out the Candle.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Oh God! my Husband.

sp.speaker: 1 Lover.
sp.p: 'S death! What shall we do?

sp.speaker: Yo. Mag.
sp.p: Now it thickens; an admirable Plot.

sp.speaker: Husb.
sp.p: Oh my Shins, my Shins!
sp.stage: Takes up the Candle, and blows it in again.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: 'Tis as we wisht.

sp.speaker: Yo. Mag.
sp.p: There's a turn: Who would expect that? As great a turn as can be, from darkness to light: Can any thing be greater?

sp.speaker: 1 Lover.
sp.p: Now we are undone again.

sp.speaker: Husb.
sp.p: Now tremble at my Vengeance, thou most perfidious Strumpet; for I will kill thee before thou prayest.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: What means my dearest Honey?

sp.speaker: Husb.
sp.p: Oh thou salacious Jade! Canst thou ask, when that stallionRogue is there?

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: What Rogue? Art thou mad? Here's no Body.

sp.speaker: Husb.
sp.p: No Body? Why, who's that? thou most lascivious Quean!

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Where?

sp.speaker: Husb.
sp.p: There.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: I see no Body; thou art distracted.

sp.speaker: 1 Lover.
sp.p: How I adore her for her Wit..

sp.speaker: Husb.
sp.p: What Fellow's that, Huswife?

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Which? I see none.

sp.speaker: Husb.
sp.p: But I do; and have at him first.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Hold, my Dear; if thou seest any Body, it is the Devil; and if thou strik'st it, it will tear thee in pieces.

sp.speaker: Husb.
sp.p: Are you mad? Do you see no Body there?

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: No, Heaven knows, not I. Oh Heaven! the House is haunted: What does it look like?

sp.speaker: Husb.
sp.p: Oh Lord! it looks like a Man: hah! Methinks he has glaring Eyes: Oh! Oh! I see his cloven Foot; this is that that struck me just now: Oh Heaven help me!

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Oh help? I swound, I swound.

sp.speaker: Husb.
sp.p: Oh my dear Wife! Oh the Devil!

sp.speaker: 2 Lover.
sp.p: Have I caught you, Sir?

sp.speaker: 2 Lover.
sp.p: Since you have, for the Lady's sake, don't discover me.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Oh! Is it there still my Dear?

sp.speaker: Husb.
sp.p: No, I think 'tis gone; hah! 'tis vanisht.

sp.speaker: Yo. Mag.
sp.p: Well, it concerns me so, Iam not able to bear it.

sp.speaker: Husb.
sp.p: My poor Dear! I have wrong'd thee; prithee forgive me.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: I am always abus'd thus by you; I am too honest.

sp.speaker: Husb.
sp.p: Prithee forgive me, I will never tax thee more; but I must change my House, if it be thus haunted.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: I am afraid to live here any longer; do, my Dear.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: I see Bellamore minds no Woman but my foolish Sister (whom, I fear, he takes for me) yet she is so ridiculously fond of that Fool, that he cannot reasonably imagine I would be.

sp.speaker: Self.
sp.p: Do you not see how fond that pretty Creature is of me? I make no doubt but I shall enjoy her Person.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Damnation on this Rascal! Can a Woman of so much Wit like him? Ill watch her; Women have odd, fantastick Appetites, and there's no trusting of 'em.

sp.speaker: 2 Lover.
sp.p: Tis too apparent that she's false to me, and I'll revenge it, by discovering her to her Husband, for all her trick.

sp.speaker: 1 Lover.
sp.p: I will cut your throat, if you offer it.

sp.speaker: 2 Lover.
sp.p: Nay then, you Rascal, have at you.

sp.speaker: Husb.
sp.p: Oh villainous Woman! Are these Spirits? Now I am convinc'd I know one Whoremaster too well to believe it.

sp.speaker: 1 Man.
sp.p: Zounds you Rogue! Do you play your tricks with me?
sp.stage: [the Back he takes it to be

sp.speaker: 2 Man.
sp.p: Have at you, Dog.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Impudent Rascals! Have at you all.
sp.stage: of the House; the Actors run off; Ladies run out shricking.

sp.speaker: Self.
sp.p: I will make good the Lady's Retreat.
sp.stage: [He retreats behind the Ladies, with his Sword drawn.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Where is this Selfish gone? I must watch him and the Lady.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: What Rascals and Cowards are these Bullies? Where are the Ladies? Boy, go out, and bid the Players go on.
Oh Madam! I am asham'd of this disorder.

sp.speaker: Theod.
sp.p: Are you not hurt, Sir?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Only a little in the Hand.

sp.speaker: Theod.
sp.p: Come to morrow, and my shock Dog shall lick you whole. A Hurt in the Hand? Why, 'tis gotten with opening of Oysters, and cured with a Cobweb.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: If you will but pity the Wounds you give your self, I'll ne'r complain to you of any other.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: Theodosia may affect ill Nature, which perhaps her Heart is no more guilty of than mine. But, I am sure, I am extremely troubled at your Hurt, and would not have you neglect it.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: You are too obliging; 'tis slight, and worth neither of our cares.

sp.speaker: Gart.
sp.p: Oh Lord! Mr. Carlos is hurt, I shall swoun: Oh dear Sir! my Heart went pit a pat all the while you were fighting.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: That pretty Heart should only leap for joy.

sp.speaker: La. Busy.
sp.p: Sir, Pray let me be so happy, as to apply my white Oyntment; 'tis very soveraign for a green Wound.

sp.speaker: La. Cheat.
sp.p: I have a Balsom that never fails, and I were most unhappy, if one I esteem so well, should miscarry for want of it.

sp.speaker: Theod.
sp.p: Here's a doe about a slight Hurt; a Butcher at the Bear Garden makes nothing of forty such: I would have the Sun shine through my Servant now and then.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: You would have one serve you as they do a Mountebank, to be run through for him.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: I cannot rest till I see if Bellamore be wounded.

sp.speaker: Actor.
sp.p: Sir, We cannot go on with our Play, one of our young Women being frighted with the Swords, is fallen into a Fit, and carried home sick.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Boy, Go and find the Company; I have prepar'd an Entertainment upon the Stage; we'll have an Entry, a Song, or some Musick; there is no loss of the Play; this Prickett can write none but Low Farce, and his Fools are rather odious than ridiculous.

sp.speaker: Theod.
sp.p: You are once in the right.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: My cruel Mistress! You see I had some Favour from every one but your self.

sp.speaker: Theod.
sp.p: I believe it has cost you five pound in penny gleek, to get the good Will of the old Ladies; and the hopes of Marriage has prevalled upon the young ones.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: I was never so serious as that comes to, with any but yourself.

sp.speaker: Theod.
sp.p: No more of this; I accept your Entertainment.
sp.stage: The Scene changes to the Stage and Scenes.

sp.speaker: Self.
sp.p: Now if your Love has any resolution, you may enjoy me, and make your self the happiest Lady in Town, and please me too.

sp.speaker: Gart.
sp.p: Indeed you are so well bred, and so much a Gentleman, the Ladies cannot but love you.

sp.speaker: Self.
sp.p: I have no reason to complain.

sp.speaker: Gart.
sp.p: And then you dress so finely.

sp.speaker: Self.
sp.p: Indeed most young Fellows when they come to Town, dress at me: But, pretty Creature, let us retire.

sp.speaker: Gart.
sp.p: What you please, dear Sir, if you'll be civil.

sp.speaker: Self.
sp.p: Pretty Soul! how she loves me? I am a Rogue to be false to these poor Creatures: While they divert themselves with the vulgar Entertainments of Musick and Dancing, I will steal the happiest minute that Love and Beauty can afford.

sp.speaker: Gart.
sp.p: You shall not need to steal, I'll give you any thing: But will you make a Song on me?

sp.speaker: Self.
sp.p: Thou shalt be my Chloris, my Phyllis, Coelia, my All: Let's away my Dear.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Whither is that Rascal carrying Isabella? She must do this on purpose to make me mad; for I can never believe she can like Selfish. I'll follow.

sp.speaker: Stan.
sp.p: Well, You must be my Mistress; my Heart beats, and I have a thousand Disorders upon me, which none but she can cause.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: It beats a false Alarm for once; you see I am not she, but she is some-where behind the Scenes; pray go, and look after her.

sp.speaker: Theod.
sp.p: Prithee pull off thy Mask, and conceal thy self no longer.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: Do not discover me. I hear Bellamore keeps a Player; I am resolved to watch him, and see if I can make any Discovery.

div.stage: Enter Lady Cheatly, Lady Busy, Prigg, and Maggot.

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.p: Madam, Your Ladyship is so pester'd with this Gamester Prigg, that I cannot have time to talk with you.

sp.speaker: L. Cheat.
sp.p: I am so; and I have Business of great concernment, to confer with you about; wou'd I were rid of him.

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.p: I'll have a trick for him.

sp.speaker: Prig.
sp.p: Sirrah Maggot! I will not suffer you to talk to my Lady; she is mine, you old Fool.

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.p: Come out, you young Blockhead, and let our Swords try whose she is.

sp.speaker: Prig.
sp.p: Let's fight here; I would have my Mistress see how I put in my Pass, and what a yerk I give it.

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.p: Thou o're-grown Coward!

sp.speaker: L. Cheat.
sp.p: Gentlemen, I must not suffer quarrelling before me; Mr. Prigg be more temperate.

sp.speaker: Prig.
sp.p: I will, Madam; though 'tis hard, when Love or Honour bids me draw.

sp.speaker: Yo. Mag.
sp.p: Gentlemen, Be not so much troubled, that the Play was interrupted by the Bullies; for I have a Poem about me, which I'll entertain you with, that perhaps may be more agreeable; I will read it to you.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: But first let's have a Dance.

sp.speaker: Yo. Mag.
sp.p: With all my Heart.

sp.speaker: L. Cheat.
sp.p: Do you hear, Carpenter? Can you make the Machine's Work? I shall have use of'em.

sp.speaker: Carpent.
sp.p: Yes, Madam.

sp.speaker: L. Cheat.
sp.p: Pray be ready when I give you Order: Do you hear? Thus. Let us all sit and see this Dance.

sp.speaker: L. Cheat.
sp.p: My Brother's here; what shall we do now?

sp.speaker: Lump.
sp.p: I am asham'd, Sister, of your Sin, and Vanity, and cannot in conscience let you alone in your evil ways. What makes you in this wicked place? this sink of sin? this house of Abominations? where wise men, and godly men are abus'd: It is great wickedness, and I cannot be silent; my zeal and wisdom will not let me be silent.

sp.speaker: L. Cheat.
sp.p: Brother, Have a little Breeding, as well as Zeal and Wisdom, and do not disturb the Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Lump.
sp.p: I care not for Breeding; shall Zeal and Wisdom give place to that? I say, 'tis not lawful, 'tis sinful, 'tis abominable, to come under the Roof with these Hornets; there is Wit, flashy Wit stirring here; and I would as soon be in a Pest-house.

sp.speaker: L. Cheat.
sp.p: I must comply with those I have designs upon, for my Fortune's sake, and for my Daughter's.

sp.speaker: Lump.
sp.p: That does something mollifie the sin; but it is too great, and I cannot bear it: Cannot you take religious Courses, in order to your design, and then you may serve Heaven and your self together? You are foolish, very foolish and have no method in you.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: This Gentleman is going to read a pious Poem to us; pray do not interrupt him.

sp.speaker: Lump.
sp.p: Sir, I must interrupt him, I have a Call, a great Call to it; all Poetry is abominable, and all Wit is an Idol, a very Dagon, I will down with it; all the wise and godly Party of the Nation hate Wit..

sp.speaker: Yo. Mag.
sp.p: None but Fools hate Wit, and those that cannot think; for my part, I will venture my Blood in defence of Poetry.

sp.speaker: Lump.
sp.p: I will preach against it, while I have breath.

sp.speaker: Yo. Mag.
sp.p: Peace, Fool! I will read on.

sp.speaker: Lump.
sp.p: Sister, You shall not hear it; 'tis prophane, abominable, a
Grace-resisting, Soul-destroying, Conscience-choaking, most unutterably Sin-nourishing thing, and I cannot bear it; I cannot suffer it.
sp.stage: Lady Cheatly whistles, two mock-Devils descend and fly up with Lump.
sp.p: Murder, murder, What dost thou do, Satan? whither dost thou fly with me?

sp.speaker: Yo. Mag.
sp.p: This is very well: Ha! ha! ha! now I may read in quiet.

sp.speaker: Prig.
sp.p: Pray, my Dear, let's be going; I hate this Wit; I think Mr. Lump is in the right.

sp.speaker: L. Cheat.
sp.p: Sit but a while, and I'll go.

lg.l: Beauty, thou great preserver of the World,
By which into dead Lumps quick life is hurl'd.

sp.speaker: L. Cheat.
sp.p: So, now I shall have time to speak with you.
sp.stage: [Ex. Mag. L. Cheatly, Lady Busy. Prigg and Young Maggot are carried up in their Chairs, and hang in the Air.

sp.speaker: Prig.
sp.p: Hold! hold! Murder! murder! What a Devil do you mean? My Dear! Honey! Where is my Lady? Madam! Madam!

sp.speaker: Yo. Mag.
sp.p: What can this mean? But hold, I'll read on, if you will. Beauty, thou great, &c.

sp.speaker: Prig.
sp.p: They are all gone; what shall I do? Pox on your Wit, Sirrah! This is your Wit, you damn'd Wit, you.

sp.speaker: Yo. Mag.
sp.p: You lye, Fool! 'tis a Wheadle, a Cross-bite of the Widow's.

sp.speaker: Prig.
sp.p: Oh you damn'd scribling, sensless, sing-Song Wit!

sp.speaker: Yo. Mag.
sp.p: Oh you damn'd, gaming, Jocky, hunting, Tennis-Fool!

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Hell, and Damnation! What have I seen? A Curse on all the Sex! Is this the Vertue she pretended to? To be lewd with so despicable a Coxcomb as Selfish, so nauseous a Fellow! Death and Hell!

sp.speaker: Prig.
sp.p: Hark you, Bellamore: Prithee help me down.

sp.speaker: Yo. Mag.
sp.p: Pray let me down.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Pox on you both!

sp.speaker: Self.
sp.p: Ah Bellamore! I am the happiest Man, I think, that ever the Sun shin'd on: I have enjoy'd the prettiest Creature, just now, in a Room behind the Scenes: I cannot help telling of thee, because thou art my Friend; Faith! telling is half the pleasure to me; for I confess to thee, I think, we that are happy in Lady's Affections, make Love, as much for Vanity, as any thing else: You know the Lady.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Damn the Dog.
'Twas one of my Lady Cheatly's Daughters; which of'em was it?

sp.speaker: Self.
sp.p:
Well, I can keep nothing from thee; it was one of 'em; but
upon your Honour keep it secret; guess which; they are both desperately in Love with me, hah!

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Impudent Rascal and Coxcomb!
sp.stage: [He strikes him, then beats him with his Sword.

sp.speaker: Self.
sp.p: What ill Breeding is this? Are you distracted?

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: Heaven! What's the matter? Hold, hold.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Be gone, Rascal, or I'll run you through.

sp.speaker: Self.
sp.p: I will not be uncivil before a Lady, another time I shall call you to an account; an ill-bred Fellow!

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: What's the reason of this Quarrel?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Here, Carpenter.

sp.speaker: Carpent.
sp.p: Here, Sir.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Let down those Fools, and dispose of 'em, so they may not trouble us.

sp.speaker: Prig.
sp.p: So, this is well.

sp.speaker: Yo. Mag.
sp.p: Bellamore, I thank you.
sp.stage: [Carpenter lets 'em down and presently they sink down and roar out.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: You know too well the occasion of the Quarrel.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: What do you mean?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Is all your pretence of Vertue come to this? and must my Love be thus rewarded?

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: This rudeness of yours amazes me.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: 'Tis I have cause to be amazed, to be refus'd the Favour, and you to grant it to that filthy Fool, Selfish; there's nothing but dissembling, treachery, and ingratitude in your whole Sex.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: A Favour to Selfish? The Fool of all the World, I scorn and hate the most; but now I see you'll give me occasion to rank you with him.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: No, you shall never rank me with him; I scorn to be oblig'd to one, who is so free to lay out her self upon such an Ass.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: Has that vain Rascal lyed on me? and do you believe him?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: My Eyes will not lye, Madam; I will trust them; and though you have let down your Skirt, I know the Petticoat too well.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: Unworthy Man! I could stab thee for this Affront, but that thou art not worthy of a serious thought. Is this the Petticoat you mean? What has my foolish Sister done?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: How? this is not the Petticoat.
Heaven and Earth! 'twas Gartrude, I see now.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: I scorn and hate thee for thy base suspicion, more than all Mankind.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Madam, I am a Dog, a Villain, not fit to live; kill me, for if you forgive me not, I'll do't my self.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: I ll never see thy odious Face again, do what thou wilt; farewel base Man.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Hell and Devils! What has my Rashness brought me to?

sp.speaker: Stan.
sp.p: Pretty Miss! Be not so troubled; I have us'd thee kindly, very kindly.

sp.speaker: Gart.
sp.p: Kindly? Oh sad! I'll tell my Mother what you have done to me, so I will.

sp.speaker: Stan.
sp.p: Thou art not mad, Child! Prithee don't.

sp.speaker: Gart.
sp.p: But I was mad to let you be so uncivil, and I will tell her; here she is.

div.stage: Enter La. Busy, La. Cheatly, and Maggot.

sp.speaker: Stan.
sp.p: S'heart! What a Fool she is? I'll not stand the brunt.

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.p: Well, Madam, I'll dispatch the business, and wait on you again.

sp.speaker: Gart.
sp.p: Oh Madam! what shall I do? what shall I do?

sp.speaker: L. Cheat.
sp.p: What's the Matter?

sp.speaker: Gart.
sp.p: I thought what 'twould come to; you charg'd me to be civil to Stanmore, and I am deflowr'd, so I am.

sp.speaker: L. Cheat.
sp.p: Oh Heaven! What did he ravish you?

sp.speaker: Gart.
sp.p: No; because you bid me be civil to him, I consented; I was afraid to anger you, Madam.

sp.speaker: L. Cheat.
sp.p: Civil? that was civil with a vengeance; let me come, I'll knock her on the head, filthy Creature.

sp.speaker: L. Busy.
sp.p: Hold, Madam; be wise, and make the best on't; let me alone to manage this Affair: Come, pretty Mrs. Gartrude, has he made no Settlement upon thee?

sp.speaker: Gart.
sp.p: He settled nothing but himself upon me, that I know.

sp.speaker: L. Cheat.
sp.p: No, that's the Plague; I knew there was no Settlement, if that had been done, it had been somewhat.

sp.speaker: L. Busy.
sp.p: Go to; be patient; let me alone; withdraw, good Madam, and trust me.
Come on, Mr. Stanmore, I must talk with you a little.

sp.speaker: Stan.
sp.p: Now for a wise Lecture.

sp.speaker: L. Busy.
sp.p: Look up, pretty Miss, come on.

Sir, My Lady Cheatly is a worthy Person, and of good quality; right— Mrs. Gartrude is a very pretty young Lady— true— nor is it fit my Lady (who has entertain'd you so often, and so nobly, in her house) should be abus'd— do you conceive me— nor is it fit that this pretty young thing should be injur'd— you understand me—

sp.speaker: Stan.
sp.p: Your Ladyship speaks like an Oracle.

sp.speaker: L. Busy.
sp.p: Very good— this pretty thing, I understand, has been very kind to you. Very well—

sp.speaker: Stan.
sp.p: Fie Miss! fie! tell tales out of School? if she has, I am sure, I was as kind as she could be for her heart.

sp.speaker: L. Busy.
sp.p: Very good— Come, I understand you— Ah what pleasure 'tis to lye by such a sweet Bed fellow! such pretty little swelling Breasts! such delicate black sparkling Eyes! such a fresh Complexion! such red powting Lips! and such a Skin! I say no more— in short, she would make a Husband very happy— Come, let it be so— and let no more words be made of this Matter.

sp.speaker: Stan.
sp.p: I'll do what I can to help her to one.

sp.speaker: L. Busy.
sp.p: Go to— that's well said— your self then be the Man— Oh how the Town will envy you the enjoyment of so fine a Lady!

sp.speaker: Stan.
sp.p: S'heart, Madam, what do you take me for? if you knew all, what need I marry for the Matter?

sp.speaker: L. Busy.
sp.p: Go to; she may make as good a Wife as can be for all that; have you not many Examples?

sp.speaker: Stan.
sp.p: No, Madam; I have made a Vow of Chastity that way, which I will never break.

sp.speaker: L. Busy.
sp.p: I would not my Lady should know this for the World, she would be reveng'd to the last degree: Let me tell you, you have been very uncivil.

sp.speaker: Stan.
sp.p: Faith, Madam! I think not.

sp.speaker: Gart.
sp.p: Yes, but you have been uncivil though, that you have.

sp.speaker: L. Busy.
sp.p: Go to— do you mind? Do you think a Family is to be dishonoured? is that like a Gentleman— nay, not but that humane frailty must be pass'd by— for young people, when they meet, are apt and lyable— 'tis confess'd— but then— ay what then?— why, your Gentlemen and your worthy Persons strive to make it good: Very well— but how is it to be made good? hum— why, either by Marriage, or Settlement.

sp.speaker: Stan.
sp.p: I have a private Reason must keep me from doing either.

sp.speaker: L. Busy.
sp.p: No, no, that won't pass: I know you are too much a Gentleman; besides, you made me promise you would keep; and let me tell you, my Honour is concern'd in it, and I would not have my Honour touch'd for the World.

sp.speaker: Stan.
sp.p: I did not promise to keep for another, as I must if I keep her.

sp.speaker: Gart.
sp.p: You do not say true then.

sp.speaker: L. Busy.
sp.p:
Fie, Mr. Stanmore, that you should say such an ungentile thing! Come, Miss, bear up, and do not cry: how can you endure
to see a young Lady's tears, and not melt: Come on; pretty Miss, I am sure you will be kind, and constant to Mr. Stanmore, will you not?

sp.speaker: Gart.
sp.p: Yes, yes.

sp.speaker: L. Busy.
sp.p: Good. Why look you, Sir, I know you are a worthy Gentleman, and will consider of a Settlement, such as befits a Gentlewoman.

sp.speaker: Stan.
sp.p: No, Madam: Selsish, this Evening, in a green Room, behind the Scenes, was before-hand with me; she ne'r tells of that: Can I love one that prostitutes her self to that Fellow?

sp.speaker: L. Busy.
sp.p: How's this?

sp.speaker: Gart.
sp.p: Oh sad, that you should say such a thing! I am sure, he will not say so for the World; would I might ne'r stir out of this place alive now, if I did.

sp.speaker: Stan.
sp.p: I had it from his own Mouth.

sp.speaker: Gart.
sp.p: O Lord, I ll be far enough, if you had! I'm sure, he's too fine a Gentleman, and too well bred, to tell such a grievous lye of a Lady; I am sure, he did not say so, that he did not.

sp.speaker: Stan.
sp.p: How she commends him?

sp.speaker: L. Busy.
sp.p: You know, Selfish is the vainest Fellow that ever was born; can you believe that Coxcomb? it is not generous.

sp.speaker: Stan.
sp.p: Shall I believe Bellamore's Eyes? He saw it: Good Madam, be pleas'd to forbear your Tricks upon me. Farewel, I hate the leavings of a Fool; I'll as soon eat the Meat he has chew'd, or wear his foul Linnen after him. Adieu, good Madam.

sp.speaker: L. Busy.
sp.p: Now see what your Indiscretion has done; did I not tell you, Selfish would undo you?

sp.speaker: Gart.
sp.p: Oh what shall I do! what shall I do! Does your Ladyship think, you could not get Mr. Selfish to marry me? Oh! he's the prettyest Man; I could live and die with him.

sp.speaker: L. Busy.
sp.p: Go to; you will utterly ruine your self: Do you think, a Fellow that has been so base to boast of your Kindness, will marry you? Peace, I say; I will try another; Young Maggot shall be the Man.

sp.speaker: Gart.
sp.p: I can't abide him.

sp.speaker: L. Busy.
sp.p: I say, go to— you must marry him, if he will, and be glad on't too: Stanmore has forsaken you; Selfish can't keep you; your Mother will turn you out of doors, and you will starve. Come, come, along with me, and be better advis'd.

div.trailer: The End of the Fourth Act.

div.head: ACT V.

sp.speaker: Prig.
sp.p: NOw, Madam, Ihope, you will be perswaded to dispatch this business of Wedlock this Morning; 'twould be much more convenient for me than to morrow, because I am to go to Newmarket to a Cock-Match: I have lay'd fifty pound upon Jack-an. Apes, against Tom Prigg's Boxen Beak; my Dun fights a Battel with Tom Whiskin's Duck Wing, for fifty pound.
'T will be the best Sport in the World; I would fain marry to day, and go thither to morrow: Will your Ladyship go and see it?

sp.speaker: L. Cheat.
sp.p: No, pray, Sir, if that be the best Sport in the World, see that first, and marry afterwards.

sp.speaker: Prig.
sp.p: New market's a rare place, there a Man's never idle: We make Visits to Horses, and talk with Grooms, Riders, and Cock keepers, and saunter in the Heath all the Forenoon; then we dine, and never talk a word but of Dogs, Cocks, and Horses; then we saunter into the Heath again; then to a Cock-Match; then to a Play in a Barn; then to Supper, and never speak a word but of Dogs, Cocks, and Horses again; then to the Groom-Porters, where you may play all night. Oh, 'tis a heavenly Life! we are never idle.

sp.speaker: L. Cheat.
sp.p: For ought I see, you are never otherwise.
Heaven! Is this Villain return'd?

sp.speaker: Stew.
sp.p: Yes, Perfidious Woman! I am return'd, and will make you know, that I am not to be us'd so. What? to be clap'd under Hatches, and carried to the Indies, to be sold for a Slave? a fine Design truly: But, come, Madam, I will make you know your Lord and Master.

sp.speaker: L. Cheat.
sp.p: What means your Impudence?

sp.speaker: Stew.
sp.p: Impudence! to command my Wife? Know your Duty.

sp.speaker: Prig.
sp.p: Your Wife? Why, you are her Man; are you not?

sp.speaker: Stew.
sp.p: What Fellow's this? I must have new Orders; I must have no such Customers about my House.

sp.speaker: L. Cheat.
sp.p: Call a Constable, the poor Fellow's distracted.

sp.speaker: Stew.
sp.p: No, but I may make the Lady so, if she persists in her Impudence.

sp.speaker: Brig.
sp.p: Thou art very sawcy to thy Lady and Mistress.

sp.speaker: Stew.
sp.p: Peace, Fool! Sawcy to my Wife?

sp.speaker: Prig.
sp.p: Fool? hah, Fool! What a Pox would you be at?

sp.speaker: L. Cheat.
sp.p: Impudent Villain! thy Wife?

sp.speaker: Stew.
sp.p: Most audacious Woman! Darest thou deny it? Was I not married to you yesterday in your own Chamber, by a Parson of your own chusing.

sp.speaker: L. Cheat.
sp.p: How dar'st thou affirm so impudent a Lye? Where didst thou dream this?

sp.speaker: Prig.
sp.p: I have my Que; I'll have my hand in the Plot.

sp.speaker: Stew.
sp.p: Why, thou most infamous of Women! Canst thou deny this?

sp.speaker: L. Cheat.
sp.p: Yes, thou most impudent of Rascals, I will deny it to all the World, and I have taken care that thou shalt never prove it.

sp.speaker: Stew.
sp.p: Hell and Devils! Is there one amongst you like this Woman?

sp.speaker: L. Cheat.
sp.p: Well, if you will be quiet, and stir no farther in this Business, a thousand pound is yours; if not, you never shall have me, nor any thing of mine. Marry such a Fellow?

sp.speaker: Stew.
sp.p: No, base Woman! I'll undo thee.

sp.speaker: L. Cheat.
sp.p: 'Tis out of your power, Fool, you have sworn to all my Bonds and Deeds already.

sp.speaker: Stew.
sp.p: Most Vile of Cheats! I'll find your Parson, if he be in England.
sp.stage: Enter Prigg, in the Habit of a Parson.
sp.p: Oh happy Fortune! here he is.

sp.speaker: L. Cheat.
sp.p: What means this Coxcomb, Prigg?

sp.speaker: Stew.
sp.p: Now, Madam, did not you marry me to this Lady yesterday? Speak, upon the word of a Priest.

sp.speaker: Prig.
sp.p: Yes, I did.

sp.speaker: Stew.
sp.p: Now, what says your Impudence? I thought I should catch you: Were you so cunning to deny it? Where do you live, Sir?

sp.speaker: Prig.
sp.p: Madam, Pray help me off with my Habit.

sp.speaker: L. Cheat.
sp.p: This is well enough.

sp.speaker: Stew.
sp.p: Hah! What a Devil's this? Were you the Parson?

sp.speaker: Prig.
sp.p: Yes, good Sir.

sp.speaker: L. Cheat.
sp.p: Yes, This was my Chaplain, you sawcy Fool! Could you think, I would marry such a filthy Fellow as you are?

sp.speaker: Stew.
sp.p: I will give you to understand, Madam, that 'tis a good Marriage, and I'll bring you into the Court to swear it, Sir.

sp.speaker: Prig.
sp.p: If you do, Sir, I'll hold six to four, I forswear it, Sir.

sp.speaker: Stew.
sp.p: Why, sure you dare not?

sp.speaker: Prig.
sp.p:
By Heaven, I dare, and will not forswear my self for such a Widow, Gentlemen forswear themselves to get Whores, and make
nothing on't: Be gone out of my house, she is mine, Fellow, be gone, I say.

sp.speaker: Stew.
sp.p: Curse on my shallow head! that I should be so credulous, to believe her to be true to me, when I was an hourly Witness of her falshood to others: I will have you my Wife, or be reveng'd to that degree; you shall repent this Treachery your whole life: I am going to visit all those you have had Business with this moneth, and I shall tell 'em such a Tale.

sp.speaker: Prig.
sp.p: I'll cut his Throat; say no more.

sp.speaker: L. Cheat.
sp.p: Pray hasten after this malicious, clamourous Rascal, and stop him some way or other; he'll invent a thousand lyes of me; get him arrested upon an Action of ten thousand pound at my Suit.

sp.speaker: Prig.
sp.p: Let me alone; I'll do as becomes a Gentleman.

sp.speaker: L. Cheat.
sp.p: This Trouble ioyn'd with that Fool my Daughter, will undo me; but I will find out Maggot, and he shall help to salve up all.
Oh Mr. Maggot! I have Business to communicate to you, of the greatest concernment to me that ever hapned.

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.p: Gad, Madam ●…o! If any Man in England understands Business, or loves it better than I do, I'll be burnt.

sp.speaker: L. Cheat.
sp.p: Every Man loves what he is good at; give me a Man of Business for my Friend: the fine Gentlemen of the Town, are like Fidlers, only good at idle hours.

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.p: There are no great Persons at this end of the Town, have any Business, but I do it for 'em; I am the busiest Man in England, and, I hope, Madam, you'll consider of my Love to Business, and to your Ladyship.

sp.speaker: L. Cheat.
sp.p: Why, that is part of the Business I am to confer with you about.

div.stage: Enter Lady Busy and Young Maggot.

sp.speaker: L. Busy.
sp.p: Madam, I beg you will retire; I have an Affair with Young Mr. Maggot, that concerns you, and Mrs. Gartrude.

sp.speaker: L. Busy.
sp.p: Mr. Maggot, I can never enough admire your Uncle Maggot's aversion to Wit and Breeding; nor can I chuse but pity you, who are like to be so great a sufferer for your Love to both.

sp.speaker: Yo. Mag.
sp.p: I glory in my suffering for so good a Cause.
