sp.speaker: L. Busy.
sp.p: Well, many a Man would be proud of such a Nephew; but is it true, that you are like to be dis-inherited?

sp.speaker: Yo Mag.
sp.p: It is as true, as I my self will ever be to Wit and Beauty; unless I will recant my Works, and for the future renounce Tropes, Figures, Similes, and all ornaments of Speech.

sp.speaker: L. Busy.
sp.p: These are hard Conditions.

sp.speaker: Yo. Mag.
sp.p: A Man of my vigorous Imagination, had as good have been born dumb: I will sing, and starve to death, like a Grashopper, e're I submit.

sp.speaker: L. Busy.
sp.p: Go to: Suppose some Friend of yours, more careful of you, than you are of your self, should find a way to compose this matter, without prejudice to your Poetry.

sp.speaker: Yo. Mag.
sp.p: That Friend should be another Apollo, if a Man, and a tenth Muse to me, if a Woman.

sp.speaker: L. Busy.
sp.p: Good. There is a Woman, a pretty one, young and rich too in the case: Very well; but how shall I come by this Woman, say you? Go to; let me alone; a fine Woman, with a good Fortune, were no ill refuge from the anger of your Uncle, hah!

sp.speaker: Yo. Mag.
sp.p: But if I should marry, what will the World say of my Wit? I had rather lose my Honour, and starve, than lose the name of a Wit..

sp.speaker: L. Busy.
sp.p: Your Reputation is establisht already; go to, consider.

sp.speaker: Yo. Mag.
sp.p: But, Madam, my Heart is engaged, and the poor Soul loves me again to madness; I did but kiss my hand to a Lady in a window t'other day, and the poor Thing fell into a Fit; she will never out-live such a hainous Tergiversation.

sp.speaker: L. Busy.
sp.p: Come, come, you know not the World; this is some soft-hearted Fool, that will be as fond of another in three days. Go to; I know the Sex better than you; but such a Reputation, such a Face, and such a Fortune!

sp.speaker: Yo. Mag.
sp.p: Nay, if she have a better Face, and Reputation, than my Gartrude, I will forswear Poetry, and write Short-hand at Conventieles, all the rest of my Life.

sp.speaker: L. Busy.
sp.p: Is she the Woman? My Lady Cheatly looks very high for her Daughter, Stanmore and several Fortunes are about her; do you conceive me?

sp.speaker: Yo. Mag.
sp.p: That's all one.

lg.l: As for my part I have chosen one,
And I'll have my Love, or I'll have none.

sp.speaker: L. Busy.
sp.p: Hold: A Lady of Fortune, Beauty, and one that loves you, and admires you for your Wit, is not to be neglected.

sp.speaker: Yo. Mag.
sp.p: How? then she has Wit too.

sp.speaker: L. Busy.
sp.p: How else should she admire it in you?

sp.speaker: Yo. Mag.
sp.p: Since she has Wit, I will see her, that's certain, and love her, if I can; if not, I'll make her some handsome excuse for't in my next Song.

sp.speaker: L. Busy.
sp.p: Well then, here she comes.
It is this pretty Gartrude: Ah! what a Bedfellow is this, with above ten thousand pound too.

sp.speaker: Yo. Mag.
sp.p: Pretty Creature! Are you she?

sp.speaker: Gart.
sp.p: Yes, that I am.

sp.speaker: Y. Mag.
sp.p: But, Madam, do you not think Marriage will spoyl my Poetry?

sp.speaker: Gart.
sp.p: I would not marry you, if I thought it would; for I love your Verses dearly.

sp.speaker: L. Busy.
sp.p: Stanmore and Selfish will hang themselves, when they hear of your good Fortune.

sp.speaker: Yo. Mag.
sp.p: Ay, so they will.

sp.speaker: Gart.
sp.p: Every Body says, they love one to ones face; but you said so behind my back; I heard you tell my Lady so, and I am resolved I will have you, though my Mother turn me out of doors, that I will.

sp.speaker: L. Busy.
sp.p: Go, get you together, loving Rogues, and let me alone to make your peace with my Lady Cheatly.

sp.speaker: Self.
sp.p: Consider my Person, and my Breeding; think not of Bellamore, he has two Ladies with Child by him, and one claims Marriage.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: You had best marry her for him, he'll give a good Portion.

sp.speaker: Self.
sp.p: I did not think so harsh a Repartee could have come out of that pretty mouth: Sure you take something ill from me; my conduct among the Ladies does not please you: I confess, I have been somewhat too general in my Addresses; but I am resolved to apply my self to you, and be less Gallant hereafter.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: Be less vain, and less a Coxcomb, and know, that nothing you forbear or do, can please or trouble me.

sp.speaker: Self.
sp.p: Were I not skill'd in the various Dispositions of your soft Sex, these words would make me despair; but I have often known such peevishness the Child of Love.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: Were I a Man, I'd cudgel you out of this conceit of your self; but as I am, I can only despise, and laugh at you.

sp.speaker: Self.
sp.p: Hah! hah! hah! You are pleasant, and I am glad to find you so: I often discover Lady's Affections to me that way; for I am sure they love me, when they are so familiar with me, my pretty Raylleur.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: Monster of Vanity! be gone.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: I beg upon my knees, you will once more hear me.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: I never will.

sp.speaker: Self.
sp.p:
It is in vain: Give her over, Bellamore; what would you have
her do, poor Lady? she loves me; dost thou think ever to get a Lady where I am? Why, my Mother has often told me, I was born with a Cawl upon my head, and she wrapt me up in her Shift, to make me lucky to Ladies.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Impudent Coxcomb! I will not disturb the house; but follow me, or I'll cut your Throat here; you are the occasion of this Storm.

sp.speaker: Self.
sp.p: With all my heart: I did intend to demand satisfaction for your ill Breeding at the Play-house, and you shall find I can fight, as well as I can make Love.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Come on, Vanity.

sp.speaker: Theod.
sp.p: I see you are resolved to watch me, to make me confess Love, as they do Witches, to make 'em own their Contracts with the Devil.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: If you would but look a little guiltily, I would take you upon suspicion.

sp.speaker: Theod.
sp.p: And so hurry me away to Execution. Alas, poor Carlos! Don't I look as if I died for thee? Are not my eyes languishing enough?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: You are pleasant, Madam, as becomes a winning Gamester.

sp.speaker: Theod.
sp.p: If I should play on, luck may turn, I think 'tis best to give over as I am.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: But consider how entirely I love you.

sp.speaker: Theod.
sp.p: Consider how little I care for you.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: The greatest Beauties are not always most sincerely loved.

sp.speaker: Theod.
sp.p: No, they are commonly like great Places, courted, and won by vain designing Knaves; and were I such, I should be yet more suspicious.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: A Man that's ready to die a Martyr, need make no other Professions, I should else—

sp.speaker: Theod.
sp.p: Talk like an Ass, of Charms and Tyranny of mine, of Chains and Slavery of yours; a Man that should over-hear you, would think you had been taken by the Turk.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: 'Tis not in your power, to make me leave loving you.

sp.speaker: Theod.
sp.p: 'Tis very unreasonable, that my indifference should not make you love me less.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: 'Tis very unreasonable, that my indifference should not make you love me more; but I will yet hope.

sp.speaker: Theod.
sp.p: Hope is a thin Diet, and may be allow'd in your Feaverish condition, and indeed is the only Food that Love can live on.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Oh, Madam, Marriage!

sp.speaker: Theod.
sp.p: Is to Love, as the Jesuit's Powder to an Ague, it stops the ●…t, and in a little time wears it quite off.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: My Dear, how dost thou?

sp.speaker: Carlos,
sp.p: Will you forgive me? Lovers take it as ill to be parted, as Men of Honour.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: I was just upon the point of yielding.

sp.speaker: Theod.
sp.p: I scorn to take Advantages; but I had reduced him to offer Marriage.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: Then, it seems, he is weary of being your Slave, and would make you his.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Madam, you should be generous, and take the weakest side. No, I am resolved ever to be her Servant, but would be glad of a nearer employment about her Person.

sp.speaker: Theod.
sp.p: Come, prithee Isabella, let's take a Turn in the Garden, and see if we can talk of something else.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Where e're I go, I shall carry my Love with me, and that will not suffer me to talk or think of any thing but your dear Self.

div.stage: Enter Bellamore and Selfish in the Field.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Come, Sir, I hope you like this Place, you are very nice in chusing one.

sp.speaker: Self.
sp.p: Yes, I like this; for here I ran one Man through, and gave another his life.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Let me see if you be Arm'd, or not.

sp.speaker: Self.
sp.p: No, I am too well bred for that.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Make ready.
And yet I am damnably afraid: But if I should not fight, the Ladies will not be so apt to love me, as they are.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Come, will you never have done?

sp.speaker: Self.
sp.p: Yes, Sir, What great hast are you in?

p.hi: Beauty, What art thou? But a fading Flower.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Beauty? What a Devil hast thou to do with Beauty? You are a damn'd ugly, ill bred Coxcomb, and the Ladies care not one jot for you. Draw.

sp.speaker: Self.
sp.p: Come on, I will vindicate my self and the Ladies.
Now for the Ladies: Do not kill me; consider, how the Ladies will hate you, if you should.
sp.stage: They sight; Bell. throws Self. down, and takes his Sword.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: No, prithee live, and be an Ass still; but trouble me no more.

sp.speaker: Self.
sp.p: Thou art a strange, rough, ill-bred Fellow, to fight so, to fling a Man down, and spoil his Cloaths; you have dirted all my Garniture, and spoil'd my Cravat: Could not you have fought easily, handsomely, and like a Gentleman? You were never bred in an Academy; they never fight thus brutally in France.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: This is ridiculous enough.

sp.speaker: Self.
sp.p: I warrant, you have done me ten pounds worth of hurt, with fighting with me; I do not know how to appear before the Ladies; I can't abide such Tricks.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Fare thee well: if I were not extremely troubled about Isabella, I would divert my self with this Coxcomb.

sp.speaker: Self.
sp.p: A Brutal Fellow! to spoil one's things thus: But I'll go home, and dress me.

sp.speaker: L. Cheat.
sp.p: You see I have considered your Passion, and how apt you are for Business; I am afraid of a Suit or two in Law, which I know you can manage.

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.p: As well as any Man in the World.

sp.speaker: L. Cheat.
sp.p: I have told you of the Insolence of the Steward, and the Artifice I used to get rid of him.

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.p: That shews, your Ladyship understands Business; how happy shall I be? how I shall laugh at, and triumph over all my Rivals?

sp.speaker: L. Cheat.
sp.p: Not a word of what has pass'd betwixt us, till a fitter opportunity.
sp.stage: Enter Prigg, with a Plaster upon his Face.
sp.p: How now, Mr. Prigg; what ayls your Face?

sp.speaker: Prig.
sp.p: Be not frighted, my Dear; tis no great hurt.

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.p: My Dear! Poor Fool, how I pity him?

sp.speaker: Prig.
sp.p: I went to stop that Rogue, your Steward, and demand satisfaction, as becomes a Gentleman; and, in fine, we drew, and after some two or three and thirty Passes, I found my self run into the Arm, and the Face; but I worsted him: Yet when I was at a Surgeon's, the Raseal got away.

sp.speaker: L. Cheat.
sp.p: I am sorry you should venture so much for me.

sp.speaker: Prig.
sp.p: Oh, Madam! 'Twas for my self; for we are to be all one Flesh: Now nothing troubles me, but that this Hurt will hinder my Journey to New-market to morrow.

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.p: He, all one Flesh with her? poor Coxcomb!

sp.speaker: 1 Scriv.
sp.p: Madam, I wonder, a Lady of Quality should be guilty of such Fraud and Covin, to write Bonds with Ink, that will wear out in a Moneth.

sp.speaker: 2 Scriv.
sp.p: Other Ink, you have too, that with a Spirit rubb'd upon the Paper, will make Impression through a whole Quire.

sp.speaker: L. Cheat.
sp.p: What mean these Fellows? Are you mad?

sp.speaker: 1 Scriv.
sp.p: No, but this is enough to make us mad, for our selves, and our Clients, to be cheated of such Sums.

sp.speaker: 2 Scriv.
sp.p: Pray, Madam, give us Security, and let me renew the Bonds with my own Ink.

sp.speaker: L. Cheat.
sp.p: Go home, and sleep, and be sober.

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.p: What's the meaning of this? is my Lady a Cheat?

sp.speaker: Prig.
sp.p: This is the Rogue, your Steward's Lye.

sp.speaker: L. Cheat.
sp.p: Oh, Gentlemen! You have been with that Rascal, my Steward, the most impudent Villain, who having most of the Writings, that concern my Estate, in his hands, had the Impudence to threaten to burn 'em, unless I would marry him.

sp.speaker: Prig.
sp.p: 'Tis very true, upon my Honour.

sp.speaker: L. Cheat.
sp.p: I, by a Wile, got'em out of his hands, and he, out of revenge, for being so disappointed, has invented these malicious Lyes; but I shall lay him fast enough.

sp.speaker: 1 Cit.
sp.p: Madam, We did not think your Ladyship would put such things upon us, to give us false Notes for our Money.

sp.speaker: 2 Cit.
sp.p: Notes written with Ink that will wear out; we shall have nothing but Blanks for our Money.

sp.speaker: 1 Cit.
sp.p: Pray let me have my five hundred pound again.

sp.speaker: 2 Cit.
sp.p: And me, mine; you have not lay'd it out yet.

sp.speaker: L. Cheat.
sp.p: What, my Rogue Steward, has been with you too; has he?

sp.speaker: 2 Cit.
sp.p: Rogue! He's an honest Man, to give us notice of this Deceit: Madam, I wonder, your Ladyship is not asham'd.

sp.speaker: Prig.
sp.p: How now, Impudence! I tell you, the Steward is the Cheat, and Rogue, he has ly'd and abus'd you; my Lady is a Person of Honour.

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.p: Hah! There must be something in this; he would not be so foolish, to tell so silly a Lye.

sp.speaker: 2 Scriv.
sp.p: My Lady is a worthy Person, and the Steward has invented these Lyes, out of revenge; because he had the Impudence to pretend to marry my Lady, and would have kept all her Writings; he'd force her to do it, but she was too hard for him: We know all.

sp.speaker: 2 Cit.
sp.p: This is strange.

sp.speaker: Lump.
sp.p: Oh thou vile Woman! thou Reprobate! thou most auda cious, seared, Conscienced Creature! Could such a wicked Branch spring from our Family, who are precious, godly Men and Women, all but thy self?

sp.speaker: L. Cheat.
sp.p: Are you mad, Brother?

sp.speaker: Lump.
sp.l: I knew you would cheat the rest.
But must you betray me, and give me false Deeds?
Must I have nothing but Blanks for my Money?

sp.speaker: 1 Scriv.
sp.p: What ayls she?

sp.speaker: 1 Cit.
sp.p: How are we cheated?

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.p: S'death! There must be some Fire under all this Smoak.

sp.speaker: Lump.
sp.p: Had it not been for this honest Man, who was troubled in Conscience, and could no longer conceal your Fraud, I had ne'r known it; but now I will make an example of you.

sp.speaker: 1 Cit.
sp.p: How, Sir? Are you a precious, godly Man, and knew of a Cheat, and would not discover it?

sp.speaker: 2 Cit.
sp.p: One of our own Church, to suffer us to be betray'd?

sp.speaker: Lump.
sp.p: I had no Call to it, till now I am my self concern'd.

sp.speaker: L. Cheat.
sp.p: Will you believe this most infamous Rascal, that would have dishonoured your Family, and having all my Writings, would have married me, or have burnt 'em? I, by seeming to consent to his desires, got 'em out of his hands, made him swear to 'em before a Master in Chancery, then I turn'd him away for a Villain, as he is.

sp.speaker: Lump.
sp.p: What say you, Sir?

sp.speaker: Prig.
sp.p: Say? I'll hold six to four, he cannot say a word.
Upon my Honour, this is all true, to my knowledge.

sp.speaker: Stew.
sp.p: She caus'd me to be clapp'd under Hatches, in a Ship going to the Indies, because I knew this Secret; and I do assure you, ye are all cheated, and in less than a Moneth, will have nothing to shew for all your Money: I cannot in Conscience but reveal this.

sp.speaker: L. Cheat.
sp.p: Impudent, lying Varlet! how darest thou affirm so devilish a Lye?

sp.speaker: Stew.
sp.p: Will you marry me yet, and I will retrieve all?

sp.speaker: L. Cheat.
sp.p: Oh Heaven and Earth! The Villain whispers me in the Ear now, and tells me, if I will marry him, he will deny all.

sp.speaker: Stew.
sp.p: Mercy upon me! Will your Ladyship's Conscience give you leave to say that? Pray, Madam, consider your Soul.

sp.speaker: 1 Cit.
sp.p: Ay, Madam, consider your Soul.

sp.speaker: 2 Cit.
sp.p: And the payment of my Money.

sp.speaker: L. Cheat.
sp.p: Heaven can witness what I say is true; even just now he ask'd me to marry him.

sp.speaker: Lump.
sp.p: If this be true, Lady Sister, I will ask your pardon.

sp.speaker: Stew.
sp.p: What need I ask that, which I have already? I am married to her.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: How!

sp.speaker: Stew.
sp.p: And her great Anger, and the Reason she would have sold me to Jamaica, was, because I could not in Conscience conceal these Deceits, though I might have had the benefit of'em.

sp.speaker: L. Cheat.
sp.p: This is so extravagantly ridiculous, it makes me laugh: I will not give a serious Answer to it.

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.p: Ha! Married? You did not consummate, I hope▪ Who married you?

sp.speaker: Stew.
sp.p: Why, the truth is, she thought to put a false Marriage upon me: When she discovered my intention, of making Restitution to those she had injur'd, she dress'd that Fellow Prigg in the disguise of a Parson, and he married us in her Bed-chamber: But I'l make her know, 'tis a good Marriage.

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.p: Did you know him in the disguise?

sp.speaker: Stew.
sp.p: No, till this day he appear'd in it to me, and then pull'd it off, to shew me 'twas a mock-Marriage, as they thought; but I will make 'em know otherwise.

sp.speaker: L. Cheat.
sp.p: This is the most amazing Impudence: Mr. Prigg, declare your self; deny it, or we are undone.

sp.speaker: Prig.
sp.p: Is there ever a Magistrate here? I will swear, that there is not one word of all this true; I know not what he means; I hold Gold to Silver he's mad.

sp.speaker: L. Cheat.
sp.p: Do you see, Brother, what a Rascal you have believ'd? and how you have injur'd me?

sp.speaker: Lump.
sp.p: Why thou wicked Locust! thou spawn of a Serpent! to invent such cursed Lyes: I'll lay thee within four Walls.

sp.speaker: Stew.
sp.p: By Heaven, 'tis all true; I'll swear it; nay, I'll swear with you for a thousand pound.

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.p: Let him swear it, that we may have his Ears.

sp.speaker: 1 Cit.
sp.p: Madam, We ask your pardon, with all our hearts.

sp.speaker: 2 Cit.
sp.p: Impudent Fellow! to abuse my Lady so.

sp.speaker: Stew.
sp.p: Let me but speak.

sp.speaker: 1 Scriv.
sp.p: No, base Fellow! thou shalt not speak.

sp.speaker: 2 Scriv.
sp.p: Abuse so worthy a Lady? Out thou wicked Fellow!

sp.speaker: Stew.
sp.p: 'Tis very fine.

sp.speaker: Lump.
sp.p: Lay an Action of ten thousand pound upon him; see who will bayl him: To my certain knowledge, she has a great Estate, and has been always a very conscientious Woman; indeed I was something amaz'd at this Story.

sp.speaker: 1 Cit.
sp.p: Ay, Sir, we believe your Worship.

sp.speaker: 2 Cit.
sp.p: We know, you are a precious, godly Man.

sp.speaker: Stew.
sp.p: Are you distracted? Well, be all ●… eated, and you will, I have discharg'd my Conscience.

sp.speaker: Lump.
sp.p: Conscience? thou Seed of Belzebub!

sp.speaker: Prig.
sp.p: Conscience? An impudent Rogue! that offers to forswear himself: I offer'd to lay him ten to one, 'twas all false, and you saw he durst not bett.

sp.speaker: 1 Scriv.
sp.p: Hang him.

sp.speaker: 2 Scriv.
sp.p: Base, lying Rogue!

sp.speaker: 1 Serg.
sp.p: I arrest you at the Suit of my Lady Cheatly, in an Action of ten thousand pounds.

sp.speaker: Stew.
sp.p: Oh vile Woman!

sp.speaker: L. Cheat.
sp.p: Away with him.

sp.speaker: 2 Cit.
sp.p: Away with him.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Away with the Rogue.

sp.speaker: Lump.
sp.p: I do beseech your pardon, Sister: I was mistaken, which I do not use to be; yet that Trick at the Play-house was base.

sp.speaker: L. Cheat.
sp.p: I could not help it; I knew not of it.

sp.speaker: 1 Cred.
sp.p: Madam, You have undone us; you gave us Bonds for two hundred pound a piece, about six Weeks since, and we have nothing but the Seals left.

sp.speaker: 2 Cred.
sp.p: All the Ink is worn out; behold here, Madam.

sp.speaker: L. Cheat.
sp.p: Impostors! lying Rogues! I owe you nothing.

sp.speaker: Lump.
sp.p: These are Instruments of this Rascally Steward's; how come they by the Seal?

sp.speaker: L. Cheat.
sp.p: From the Steward.

sp.speaker: 1 Cred.
sp.p: Are ye all mad? We had it from you, for which you had two hundred pounds a piece from us.

sp.speaker: Prig.
sp.p: Out you impudent Rogue! Get you gone.

sp.speaker: 1 Cit.
sp.p: Away, lying Fellows!

sp.speaker: Lump.
sp.p: Be gone, ye Vipers!

sp.speaker: L. Cheat.
sp.p: Now, Gentlemen, I desire you that remain, to take part of a Collation with me, and I will shew all the Evidences of my Estate to you.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: There can be no defence to suspect me, and with that Wretch Selfish too.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Jealousie, like the Small-Pox; if it comes out kindly, is never mortal; and my Love will be the stronger, and the more vigorous, for this short Distemper.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: It may relapse again.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: 'Tis past all danger now.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: And will you still give a thousand pounds down, and three hundred pounds a year, for this Tenement, notwithstanding the incumbrance of Selfish upon it.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: When I made these offers, I did not know half your worth: I was a fair Chapman for your Beauty; but your Vertue, and other Perfections, are inestimable.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: And shall I flant it in the Park with my grey Flanders, crowd the Walk with my Equipage, and be the Envy of all the Butterflyes in Town?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Forget that vain Discourse, as I have done, and take me and all I have for ever.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: Sure a Man of your Wit will never marry; every rich Fool can get a Woman that way.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Do not insult, but take me quickly to your mercy.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: I'll not deceive you: What-ever show my Mother makes, I have no Portion, nor was ever troubled at the thought of it till now.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: I am glad of it; for now my Love will be the more easily believed, and better taken.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: No, Bellamore.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: How, Madam?

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: No, I say— for were I Queen of Europe, your Love would be as well accepted as 'tis now.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: You surprize me with an Honour too great to bear.

sp.speaker: L. Cheat.
sp.p: What? Are you agreed yet? She is a foolish Girl, Sir, and looks as high as better Women.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: She's very humble, and is pleased to accept of me for a Husband, and there wants only your consent, and a few words from a Parson, to compleat my happiness.

sp.speaker: L. Cheat.
sp.p: You honour our Family, and cannot doubt of my consent: She is yours.

div.stage: Enter Lady Busy, Young Maggot, and Gartrude.

sp.speaker: L. Busy.
sp.p: I present you here with a Son and Daughter: I saw 'em married; give 'em your Blessing.

sp.speaker: L. Cheat.
sp.p: Heav'n bless you! Madam, I can never thank you enough; you have made me happy, in removing my greatest affliction.

sp.speaker: L. Busy.
sp.p: I love to put Lovers together: Vertuous actions reward themselves.

sp.speaker: Stan.
sp.p: Young Maggot married? Give you Joy, Sir: Your Love to Wit and Beauty is at length rewarded.

sp.speaker: Yo. Mag.
sp.p: I will now keep company with none but the top-Wits, and write Plays, Songs and Lampoons, in defiance of the Fop my Uncle.

sp.speaker: L. Busy.
sp.p: Not so fast: Get him to settle first.

sp.speaker: L. Cheat.
sp.p: I'll call my Brother, and the rest of my company, to be Witnesses to my happiness.

sp.speaker: Self.
sp.p: Pretty Mistress! You look to day like a delicate Picture, and Young Maggot your Foyl.

sp.speaker: Gart.
sp.p: I vow, you court me so gentilely, I shall die to part with you: I cryed in the Church, that I did, and had like to have spoyl'd all.

sp.speaker: Self.
sp.p: But will you promise me a Meeting?

sp.speaker: Yo. Mag.
sp.p: Stand off: She's mine.

sp.speaker: Self.
sp.p: You are to have her ever after; methinks you should allow her one day, to take leave of her Friends.

div.stage: Enter Lady Cheatly, Lump, Maggot, Prigg, &c.

sp.speaker: Yo. Mag.
sp.p: Uncle, Your Unkindness has made me look about me, and Heaven has blest my Wit and Poetry with a rich Wife here, Mrs. Gartrude: I won her by 'em.

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.p: Ay, Boy, I know it, and know her Fortune as well as my own: Thou art a mettled Lad, and I like thy Humour well; give me a Phillis with ten thousand pounds, I could sing one of thy own Songs my self, I am so taken with this Match.

sp.speaker: Yo. Mag.
sp.p: I hope then you will settle your Estate, as you always promised, if I married to your liking.

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.p: If I have no Children by my dear Wife, her Mother here.

sp.speaker: Prig.
sp.p: La Cheatly, your Wife, she has promis'd me Marriage.

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.p: What-e're she has promis'd you, she has perform'd Marriage with me this Morning. Be gone, Rook, they stay for thee at the Twelve-penny Ordinary.

sp.speaker: Prig.
sp.p: What say you, Madam?

sp.speaker: L. Cheat.
sp.p: 'Tis very true.

sp.speaker: Prig.
sp.p: Then you are very false.

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.p: As your Dice: Gamester, I'll hold you Cock-pit Lay, ten pound to a Crown, she's Bone of my Bone, and Flesh of my Flesh.

sp.speaker: L. Cheat.
sp.p: This is the Gentleman I'll live and die with.

sp.speaker: Prig.
sp.p: Death and Hell! I'll declare all I know.

sp.speaker: L. Cheat.
sp.p: You will declare your self a perjur'd Knave, if you do. Hark here.

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.p: What do they whisper for?

sp.speaker: L. Cheat.
sp.p: All the Steward says, is true: I am worth little or nothing; my whole Fortune a Cheat; this old Gentleman I chose, because he is governable, and loves Business, of which my broken Fortune will give him enough.

sp.speaker: Prig.
sp.p: What a Cross-bite have I scaped? This Sham was well carried on, Madam: Did you hear, old Fool?

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.p: Ounds! I am cheated, undone, and my Nephew ruin'd, and married to a Beggar.

sp.speaker: Yo. Mag.
sp.p: I must even write hard for the Play-house; I may get the reversion of the Poet Laureat's place: I thought, Uncle, you had known every foot of her Estate.

sp.speaker: Prig.
sp.p: Well, I'll go to New-market, and never have to do with a two-legg'd Jade more: I shall rook, and go to Twelve, let what will come on't.

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.p: Since she has no Fortune, I shall have no Business neither.

sp.speaker: Yo. Mag.
sp.p: None, but that which I am afraid you can't do, Uncle.

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.p: Is this a time for Wit, you Rascal, when we are both undone.
sp.stage: He beats Yo. Mag. Perriwig off, from under it drop several Copies of Verses.

sp.speaker: Stan.
sp.p: A Muss, a Muss.
A Copy of Verses upon a Flea, presented to his Mistress, in a gold Chain.

lg.l: Oh happy Flea! that maist both kiss and bite,
Like Lovers, in their height of Appetite,
Her Neck so white.
Pretty black Alderman, in golden Chain,
Who suck'st her Blood, yet putt'st her to no pain,
Whil'st I in vain.

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.p: What would become of the writing-Coxcombs, if it were not for reading ones? I'll hear no more.

sp.speaker: L. Cheat.
sp.p: If you will go on, and maintain what I have done, I shall have a good Estate yet, though it belongs of right to other People.

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.p: Right? 'Tis no matter for Right: I'll show 'em Law.

sp.speaker: Theod.
sp.p: The Plague of Marriage rages in this House; let us fly from the Infection.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: I am so sar gone, 'tis to no purpose to remove. Well, if you continue to be so unkind, you will ruine my Soul, Body, and Estate.

sp.speaker: Theod.
sp.p: How so?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Why, I can never marry any other; and in despair of you, I shall turn the most debauch'd whoring Rogue, 'twould grieve your heart to see it: I shall never be able to sleep without my three Bottles, and a fresh Woman every night.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: 'Tis an act of Charity to redeem him.

sp.speaker: Theod.
sp.p: The Devil seldom loses any thing by Matrimony; they most commonly grow worse for't.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: I will lead a solid, sober, Husbandly life, if you will marry me; if not, Whoring and Drinking will ensue.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: Nay, now I must judge against you: You have lost your Wager, and you must pay it; you have confest to me you lov'd him infinitely.

sp.speaker: Theod.
sp.p: Believe her not, I deny it.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Though I distrust my self, I must believe my fair Judge: I will have a Canonical Bom-Baily, and arrest you upon Execution.

sp.speaker: Theod.
sp.p: I will have a Moneth's time; you shall be so long a Probationer, before you enter in the Order.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: In hope of your good Nature, I will press no farther at this time: Now you that have reacht at your Inn of Matrimony, will pray for us Travellers upon the Road.

sp.speaker: Stan.
sp.p: So, Gentlemen, we have lost ye, ye are not Men of this World▪ now make much of your Matrimonial Bonds; I am glad, I have done my Business without 'em.

sp.speaker: Self.
sp.p: Ladies are so kind to me, I need never marry one for the matter. Well, I will go home, and put on a very delicate, neat, convenient Suit, to dance with the Brides in here.

sp.speaker: Lump.
sp.p: I give you all Joy. You see. Sister, how things prosper, when godly Men are the Instruments. I say to all, to all of you I say,

lg.l: Be godly, observe Method, and be wise;
Car. Most excellent means to cover Cheats and Lyes.
IN troubled Times, like these— the Ancients chose
T'exhibit Feasts and Plays, and publick Shows.
By such Diversions t'allay men's Fears,
Compose their Minds, and mollifie their Cares.
If they did well then, now your Mirth to raise,
Were of such merit, you th'attempt should praise.
But 'tis a Task too hard for Comedy,
Which ne'r agen expects good Days to see.
The num'rous Herd of Fopps and Knaves arise,
Such as to Poets should be lawful prize,
Whom they like Magistrates ought to chastize.
Th' Embargo's lay on Wit, and stop our Trading,
If noted Knaves or Coxcombs be the Lading:
But this Proceeding would be too severe,
Whom the Town scorns sure we may laugh at here.
All Prodigies to publick Marts should come,
Heav'n made not Coxcombs for a private Room.
If sullen Fools would make no sport to th' Nation
We lose the only use of their Creation.
If such be drawn unlike, we punish none,
And if too like some Fopps those persons own.
Our Poet therefore Sale-work Habits makes,
But of particular Men no Measure takes.
Variety of Garments we expose
For Wits for Knaves, for Fools, all sort of Cloaths.
If any want that Honesty, or Wit,
To think our Fools or Knaves their Persons hit,
Here they may have 'em, and w' are glad they sit.
